screening_results.reason: fMRI study of social processing (peer influence on social media) with healthy participants implied, but participants described as "adolescents" and ages not specified. Inclusion requires participants aged 17–65; abstract insufficient to confirm adult age/eligibility. Include for full-text review to verify ages and health status.

This is a critical appraisal/review of naturalistic stimuli in neuroscience, not an original fMRI study. The abstract describes a review of literature and does not report fMRI data or a healthy adult participant sample. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract is a methodological/theoretical review of naturalistic fMRI approaches summarizing prior findings rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. Meets exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses; insufficient evidence of primary data to include.
This article is a meta-analysis/systematic review (title and abstract state meta-analysis of over 350 fMRI studies). Per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews and meta-analyses are excluded.

This is an overview/review chapter summarizing oxytocin studies (including fMRI work) in schizophrenia and spectrum samples; it does not report original fMRI data from healthy adults performing social tasks. Abstract provides no evidence of a primary fMRI experiment with healthy participants, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This paper is a review and meta-analysis of social cognition in PTSD (systematic review/meta-analysis). Exclusion criterion excludes systematic reviews or meta-analyses. The abstract does not present original fMRI data in healthy adults, so it should be excluded based on the study type.

Abstract describes a review/chapter synthesizing behavioral and neuroimaging literature rather than reporting original empirical fMRI data. No participants, fMRI methods, or social-task data are presented; thus it does not meet inclusion criteria for an fMRI study in healthy adults.

This is a review article summarizing fMRI findings in autism spectrum disorders rather than a primary fMRI study with human participants performing social tasks. Exclusion criterion met: systematic review/review article.

Abstract explicitly describes the article as a review integrating human fMRI and animal studies; it is not an original fMRI study with primary data. Exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses applies.

This is a narrative review of resting-state fMRI and social cognition rather than an original fMRI study. It does not report functional MRI data collected while human participants performed social-related tasks, nor participant groups, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Article is a review paper summarizing social neuroscience in psychiatry rather than an original fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), and the abstract gives no primary fMRI data on healthy adults.

The paper is a coordinate-based Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) meta-analysis rather than an original fMRI study. The protocol excludes systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded based on the abstract.

Abstract describes a review of social cognition in multiple sclerosis, emphasizing neuropsychological and neuroimaging studies across MS patients. It does not report an original fMRI study of social tasks in healthy adults; it appears to be a review article, which meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses or at least is not a primary fMRI study with healthy participants.

This paper is a review of the reliability of fMRI (literature review), not an original fMRI study reporting primary data from social-related tasks in healthy adults. Meets exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study using an ecological social-cognition task (listening to film excerpts and inferring characters' mental states). Includes healthy adult control groups (n=28; reproducibility sample n=14), probing perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

This is a review article summarizing neuroimaging findings in autism (discusses PET/SPECT/fMRI studies) rather than an original fMRI study of social tasks in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews and does not report fMRI data on healthy 17–65 participants.

This record is a systematic review (explicitly titled and described as a systematic review) of SCT effects in schizophrenia. Exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews/meta-analyses. Additionally, the study population is clinical (schizophrenia), not healthy adults.

Abstract reports fMRI during standardized probes of social reward and threat processing (a social-related task) and includes a matched control group of non-cocaine users aged 50–60 (within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults; full text can confirm health status of controls.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task) rather than fMRI acquired while participants performed a social-related task. Although behavioral social-cognition measures were assessed separately, the imaging was not task-based, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI during a social-related task.

Participants were children aged 8–12 (middle childhood), which falls outside the review’s required adult age range (17–65). Although it is an fMRI social task, the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion.
This is a review article (explicitly states 'In this review') and does not report primary fMRI data in healthy adults; excluded per exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract reports fMRI measurement of STS responses to a range of social and linguistic stimuli in human participants, directly addressing social processing in healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract; therefore include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Abstract investigates neural processing of social anticipation/feedback in BPD but does not state whether healthy control group or fMRI was used. As inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group and an fMRI task, the abstract is insufficient to determine eligibility; include for full-text review to confirm methods and participant groups.
Study used macaque monkeys (non-human primates) undergoing fMRI. Inclusion requires human participants aged 17–65 completing social-related tasks, so this does not meet the population criterion.

This article is a meta-analysis/review of fMRI studies (not an original fMRI study of healthy adults). Exclusion criterion excludes systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite covering social cognition.

This is a narrative review discussing resting-state fMRI findings in ASD and attempts (e.g., neurofeedback); it does not report an original task-based fMRI study involving healthy adult participants (17–65) performing social-related tasks, nor provide participant details. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI data were acquired during a dyadic social interaction task in human subjects, addressing social processing. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages, so inclusion should be confirmed at full-text review, but criteria are sufficiently met to include for full-text screening.

Abstract indicates a neurobiological (imaging) investigation of social-cognitive/empathy deficits; while it focuses on psychopathy, it likely includes comparison with healthy controls and involves social-related processing. Abstract lacks explicit fMRI and healthy-participant details, so include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and presence of healthy adults.

Abstract reports fMRI data collected during a social-related decision-making task (integration of social influence and reward). It is not a review/meta-analysis. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65) eligibility.

This is a methodological/review article on hyperscanning techniques, not an original fMRI study reporting functional MRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults. No participants, experimental task, or new fMRI data are described in the abstract.

The article is a meta-analysis/systematic review of neural correlates in ASD and schizophrenia rather than a primary fMRI study with healthy participants; exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses) is met.

Abstract describes a program summarizing fMRI studies of social perception including typically developing adults, but it reads like a programmatic/narrative overview and lacks clear primary participant/sample and task details. Insufficient information to confirm it reports original fMRI data on healthy adults ages 17–65. Per screening guidance, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract reports investigation of neural substrates of social cognition and face processing in a group of healthy young adults, matching social-related processing in healthy adults. However, it does not explicitly state the use of functional MRI in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm imaging modality and participant ages.

fMRI study using a social task (Cyberball exclusion/inclusion with emotional support), involving healthy undergraduate participants (n=46) within adult age range. Study examines social processing (social exclusion/support). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI BOLD study using a social-affective task (Socio-emotional Preference Task: "Do you like this face?") assessing face processing/social appraisal. Includes a healthy control group (n=13). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI valence-classification task probing agency and communion—clearly social-cognition processing. It likely involves healthy adult participants, but the abstract does not specify sample health status or ages. Because the task is social-related and the abstract lacks participant details, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This is a narrative review of semantic dementia (neuroimaging, genetics, pathology), not an original task-based fMRI study. The abstract reports no fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults and is a review article, which meets the exclusion criteria.

This is a narrative review (Annual Review of Neuroscience) summarizing fMRI and lesion findings rather than reporting original fMRI data from a sample of healthy adult participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and lacks participant/method details needed for inclusion.

The article is a selective (narrative) review, not an original fMRI study reporting human participants completing social-related tasks. It therefore does not meet the inclusion requirement of reporting functional MRI scans during a social-related task in a sample of healthy adults.
This study is a fMRI meta-analysis (and lesion study); the exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded based on the abstract.

fMRI study examining processing of social versus nonsocial gestures—directly relevant to social-related processing. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; therefore include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

Not an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. This is a review/proposal of deep brain stimulation for severe autism (plus a single case report), not a functional MRI during a social task; participants are clinical, not healthy adults.

fMRI recorded during live social interaction (reciprocal imitation), directly addressing social cognition/social-related processing. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Recommend full-text review to verify that at least one group are healthy adults (age 17–65).

Functional MRI study of self–other social processing (self and favorite teacher judgments) with a healthy control group of typically developing young adults (age-matched). Task falls under perception/understanding of self and others; not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.
The article is explicitly a meta-analysis of over 200 fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with participants. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

This article is a review synthesizing fMRI and behavioral findings in adolescence (a narrative/systematic review), not a primary fMRI study of healthy adult participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews and does not report original fMRI data from adults 17–65.

Study used functional MRI to examine neural processing of social interaction (live vs recorded speech) tapping social communication/mentalizing. Participants are human adults (healthy sample implied). It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is a resting-state fMRI study of ASD vs controls (no task-based social processing), and focuses on clinical population including children rather than fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI investigation of theory-of-mind (mentalizing), a social-related process, but does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because the abstract is insufficient to confirm the required healthy participant group, include for full-text review.

This publication is a voxel-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies (systematic meta-analysis), not an original fMRI study of participants; it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Primary empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=51) involving a social-related task (observation/processing of dynamic facial expressions—social communication and perception of others). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets age/group criteria; abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study (N=34) examining social-emotional processing (schadenfreude and fremdscham) while participants observed others’ social integrity threats—fits ‘perception and understanding of others’. Sample appears to be healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Include for full-text review.

Study examines motion perception of biological objects (faces) relevant to social cognition and includes age-matched healthy controls, but the abstract does not specify use of functional MRI or scanning modality. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI social-task data.

fMRI study examining self-referential and social stimulus processing in humans, directly addressing social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant health status or age range, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study with healthy participants performing social-related tasks (implicit/explicit eye-gaze detection and mental-state inference), fitting ‘perception and understanding of others’ construct. Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages, so include for full-text to confirm demographics.

Event-related fMRI was used to compare responses to social (face) versus non-social stimuli, addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics (healthy adults 17–65).

The study is a multimodal coordinate-based meta-analysis (CBMA) of fMRI and VBM studies, i.e., a meta-analysis. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses; abstract does not describe original fMRI social-task data in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=38) performing a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss) probing social reward/interaction—fits social-related processing constructs. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

The abstract describes a narrative review synthesizing behavioral and imaging studies of facial affect in schizophrenia rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment. It does not indicate fMRI data collected from healthy adult participants. Exclude per exclusion of reviews/meta-analyses.

This is a narrative review/chapter summarizing oxytocin research in ASD including neuroimaging; it is not an original fMRI study and provides no details of an fMRI scan with healthy adult participants performing a social task. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social working memory and social cognition, directly addressing social-related processing. It is original research (not a review). Participant health status/ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI data from 78 individuals who performed social perception and reasoning conditions within a 29-condition protocol, targeting social-related processing in healthy participants; not a review. Age range not specified—include for full-text confirmation of ages and details.

The study uses a sample of typically developing adolescents aged 14–18. The review requires healthy participants aged 17–65 (adults). Although the sample includes a few participants ≥17, the group is an adolescent sample rather than an adult sample, so it does not meet the adult age criterion.

fMRI study examining observation of others' regret, fitting 'Perception and Understanding of Others' social processing. Abstract implies experimental fMRI in healthy participants but does not report ages; insufficient detail to confirm age range—per guidelines include for full-text review.

Abstract explicitly describes this article as a 'mini-review' integrating evidence about OXTR and MRI findings rather than reporting an original fMRI study with participants and task. It is a review article, which meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

Study used task-free (resting-state) fMRI rather than a functional MRI scan during a social-related task. Although it includes healthy controls, it does not meet the requirement of task-based social processing.

Abstract reports longitudinal functional imaging in schizophrenia related to social and non-social cognition but does not specify inclusion of a healthy adult group nor that participants performed a social-related task during fMRI. Insufficient information to determine eligibility—include for full-text review.

This is a narrative review summarizing human neuroimaging literature on the cerebellum, not an original fMRI study reporting data from participants performing social-related tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract reports an fMRI study manipulating social vs solitary context during episodic memory retrieval, directly addressing social processing. Participant health status and ages are not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (healthy adults age 17–65).

Participant sample comprises children in middle childhood (approximately ages 7–13), which falls outside the eligible adult age range (17–65). Although it uses neuroimaging for social processing, it does not include healthy adults, so exclude.

Abstract describes an essay/review advocating cross-species social neuroscience; it does not report an original fMRI study, methods, or healthy adult participants. It meets exclusion criteria for reviews/meta-analyses and lacks primary fMRI data.

Resting-state fMRI study of children (ages 7–12) including ASD patients and controls; no task-based social-processing paradigm and participants are outside the required adult age range (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants (perceivers) performed a social cognition task (inferring others’ emotions) with feedback; fits social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm healthy adult group (17–65).

Participants are early adolescents (ages 10.5–13.4), not within the required adult range (17–65), and the study used resting-state fMRI and MR spectroscopy rather than a task-based fMRI social-processing paradigm. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract does not report whether task-based fMRI was used or whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included. Title focuses on PTSD but methods/results are not provided. This is not a review/meta-analysis. Insufficient information to determine eligibility, so include for full-text review.

This is a review article focusing on neuroimaging and behavioral studies in individuals with high-functioning autism (clinical population) and on visuospatial processing, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults; does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a narrative review of adolescent social brain development, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract does not report functional MRI data collected during social tasks in healthy adults (age 17–65); it focuses on adolescence and presents/ speculates on existing evidence. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used while participants made self-descriptiveness judgments (perception/understanding of self), a social cognition task. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Fits the review objective and inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria met. Abstract gives sufficient evidence of relevant fMRI social processing; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health if needed.

The article is a meta-analysis/review of fMRI studies (title and abstract indicate a meta-analysis), not an original fMRI study of healthy participants completing social-related tasks. Exclusion criterion—systematic reviews/meta-analyses—is met.

fMRI study in 15 healthy adult males using fear-inducing visual stimuli and examining oxytocin effects on amygdala/social cognition. Task examines social-related processing (social cognition/fear). Includes healthy adults aged 17–65 and is not a review.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (15 healthy males) performing a social interaction task (provoking vs non-provoking opponent) measuring retaliation. The task assesses social processing (response to others’ provocation), matching inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Not a review.

Dual-fMRI hyperscanning during an interactive social-exchange task addresses social processing and uses fMRI while participants engaged in social interaction. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; insufficient participant details for final eligibility determination, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

Two fMRI experiments examine understanding/prediction of intentions in social interactions, targeting perception/understanding of others—a social-related task. Abstract reports neuroimaging (fMRI) and social processing. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract; include for full-text to confirm sample details.

Human fMRI study (n=17) examining power vs affiliation motivation using love and power-related film clips—addresses social-related processing (affiliation/attachment). Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.

The article is a large-scale meta-analysis of fMRI studies (nearly 10,000 studies) rather than an original fMRI study with participants. The exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so exclude.

fMRI during spontaneous face-to-face conversation (a social communication task) and includes an age- and IQ-matched typically developing control group of young adult males (healthy adults). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study in individuals with autism spectrum conditions rather than a task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. No social-related task was administered; primary sample is clinical (ASC). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining speech acts (Requests vs Naming), which are social communication tasks; methods explicitly used fMRI and investigate social-interactive processing. Abstract does not state participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

The study reports an fMRI task manipulating social working memory load (social cognitive processing of mental states/traits), appears to involve healthy adults, and directly examines social-related neural processing. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

The fMRI task was the Monetary Incentive Delay (a non-social reward paradigm), not a social-related task as required. Additionally, participants were adolescents (ages not specified but likely <17), falling outside the required 17–65 healthy adult age range.
fMRI study presenting social vs non-social stimuli and includes a matched healthy control group (adults). Addresses social processing in humans and is not a review; thus meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in humans assessing emotion attribution and related judgments—tasks clearly target social processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participant age/health details.

Study used fMRI during a social-processing task (trustworthiness judgments of faces) and includes a nonclinical healthy control group. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review). Participant ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and extract data.

fMRI study using social (emotional faces) and nonsocial tasks with neurotypical control group, addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 requirement), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and sample details.

This is a review article (not an original fMRI study) focused on early/perinatal infant brain development and social cognition, not on fMRI of social processing in healthy adults (age 17–65). It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews and does not include the target adult healthy participant group.

fMRI study of face encoding (a social cognition task) that includes an age- and gender-matched healthy control group. Abstract does not specify participant ages (whether within 17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm adult age range and eligibility.

Abstract explicitly describes an Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) meta-analysis of fMRI studies. The review’s exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore this study should be excluded based on the abstract alone.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsfMRI) before/after rTMS, not an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although participants were healthy adults, the abstract does not report any social processing task or measures of social cognition, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring task-based social-related fMRI.

Primary fMRI study investigating neural correlates of social interaction (gaze, social vs. arbitrary facial expressions) — clearly a social-processing task. Not a review; likely healthy participants. Include for full-text review to confirm sample age/health.

fMRI was performed during an empathy task (social-related processing) and the study includes a healthy control group matched to patients. Age range not explicitly reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are within 17–65. No exclusion criteria met.

Although the study uses fMRI during social tasks and includes a non-clinical control group, all participants are adolescents (ages 10–18). The review requires healthy participants aged 17–65; the control group falls largely below this range, so the study does not meet the age criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study comparing neural signatures of affective self- vs other-touch (self/other perception), a social-related process. It includes neurotypical adult control participants alongside an ADHD group, meeting age and healthy participant criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study using a social cognition (theory of mind/empathy) task aligns with review objective. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17-65), so inclusion criteria cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and ages.

Abstract reports only schizophrenia patient groups (SCZ-SUD n=12; SCZ n=11) and does not include any healthy control participants. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65). Although it uses fMRI during a social-emotion task, the absence of healthy participants clearly fails the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of live face-to-face interaction and joint attention in (presumably) healthy adult participants, directly addressing social cognition/processing. It is an original empirical study (not a review/meta-analysis) and fits the review constructs (social interaction, joint attention). Abstract gives sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study where adolescents (mean age 17) viewed video clips of their parents—clearly a social-cognition/attachment task. Participants fall within the allowed age range (≥17) and are not reported to have psychiatric/neurological disorders. No exclusion criteria met; abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

This article is a review of neuroimaging studies (title and abstract state it is 'a review'), not an original fMRI study with participants. Exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so exclude.

fMRI study examining empathy and social cognition in participants (healthy group implied); task involves social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not report participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

This is an fMRI study examining neural processing of social hierarchy (social cognition/perception of others) in humans using an interactive social task, matching the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status; per screening rules, include for full-text review to confirm sample details.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social paradigm). Although it includes ASD patients and control participants, it does not involve participants completing a social-related task, so it fails the primary inclusion criterion.

This study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a functional MRI scan acquired while participants performed a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based social processing; although it examines social scales, the imaging was not task-based. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This study used resting-state fMRI (ALFF/fALFF) comparing schizophrenia patients and healthy controls; no task or social-related processing paradigm is reported. Inclusion requires task-based social processing in humans, so exclude.

The study used fMRI during processing of emotional faces—a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). It involves human participants and fMRI data suitable for inclusion. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages, so full-text review should confirm healthy adults (17–65).

Study reports task-based fMRI during social-cognitive processing (affective ToM, emotion recognition, neutral faces) and includes a matched healthy control group. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI social tasks.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no participant social-related task) and reports developmental changes in functional connectivity; it did not involve humans completing social cognition/related tasks required for inclusion. Although participants include ages within 17–65, the lack of a social task is decisive.

Abstract reports functional MRI activity (superior temporal sulcus) during two social-cognitive tasks in humans, meeting the fMRI social-processing criterion. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

fMRI study using a baby-cry attachment-related task (affiliation/attachment), includes a healthy control group (n=15) of adult mothers, and reports neural responses/functional connectivity. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Primary data study using fMRI during socio-cognitive task (viewing social/traffic videos) in adult participants comparing safe vs. dangerous drivers; examines social cognition (STS reactivity). Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing.

Not a task-based social fMRI study and participants are children. The study uses resting-state fMRI and diffusion tractography focused on language in children (ASD and child controls), not social processing in healthy adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a social-judgment (acceptance/rejection) task, includes a matched healthy control group, examines social reward processing. Not a review article. Fits inclusion criteria; full text can confirm age range if needed.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing) following intranasal oxytocin in healthy women. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; resting-state scans do not meet this criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Resting-state fMRI (no social-task was administered) and participants are adolescents (mean age ~14.6, range 10.2–18.0), not healthy adults aged 17–65. The study focuses on ASD youth and provides no eligible healthy adult task-based data; therefore it fails inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social-related task (empathy for ingroup/outgroup members — perception/understanding of others). Sample consisted of 30 healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes dyadic fMRI during eye contact, a social-interaction task relevant to the review. However, participant details (health status, ages, sample size) are not reported in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult participants (age 17–65) and other inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI study investigating social exclusion and performance evaluation (social processing constructs) with neural outcomes. Not a review. Although participant health/age not explicitly stated in abstract, the study appears to be an experimental fMRI in humans and likely involves healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm sample details.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants performing a modified prisoner's dilemma social decision-making task probing Theory of Mind/perception of others; meets review objective and inclusion criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Study used fMRI while participants watched a cinematic social-affective scene (social affiliation/ToM/embodied simulation), includes a healthy control group, and examines social-related processing. No exclusion criteria met. Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a functional MRI acquired while participants performed a social-related task. Although healthy controls are included, the absence of a task addressing social processing fails the inclusion criterion.

Abstract investigates network centrality and social-executive performance in bvFTD but does not specify task-based fMRI or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Key inclusion criteria are unclear, so include for full-text review.

Primary data fMRI study examining social attribution/mentalizing using the DISC stimuli in a sample of 22 typically developing adults (healthy adults). This meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task and healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=25 females) performing a social task (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) examining neural responses to mutual cooperation — directly addresses social processing constructs; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for the review.

Abstract reports simultaneous fMRI and EEG during a social group categorization task (social perception of in-/out-group emotions), and is not a review. However, the abstract does not state participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult (17–65) group.

fMRI study examining prosocial learning and empathy—clearly social-related processing. Abstract describes human participants performing an fMRI task benefiting self vs. others. Abstract does not specify participant health/age; insufficient detail to confirm demographics, so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

fMRI study of social decision-making (public good game) and neural correlates of social tie formation—clearly addresses social-related processing. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages, so inclusion requires full-text verification of healthy adult sample. Include for full-text review.

fMRI study evaluating reappraisal of angry faces (socially relevant perception/understanding of others) using task-based and resting-state scans. Abstract implies investigation in healthy participants but does not report ages or explicit health status; include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and health.

Functional MRI study (3T) investigating imagined triadic social interactions — clearly a social-related task engaging mentalizing and mirror systems. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI task involved social reward processing (feedback about being liked), addressing social-related processing. Participants were late adolescents aged 18–21 (within 17–65). Sample appears to be healthy individuals varying in social anhedonia; depressive symptoms were covaried. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using vocal emotional stimuli addressing perception of emotional speech (social communication/perception of others). Reports 36 healthy participants (adult sample) and is an original empirical study, not a review. Satisfies the review’s task-based fMRI and healthy adult criteria.

This is an fMRI study investigating social gaze (mutual vs averted) — a social perception/communication task — in human participants. The abstract reports brain responses in healthy subjects (no disorders mentioned). It meets the review objective and inclusion criteria; age range not specified but likely adults. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

The study used resting-state functional connectivity in MDD patients and healthy controls rather than a task-based fMRI paradigm probing social-related processing. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social task in healthy adults. Although the RTPJ and social cognition are discussed, no social task was administered, so it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

This is a methodological tutorial/review on intersubject correlation analysis, not an original fMRI study reporting scan data from healthy adults performing a social-related task. It does not meet inclusion criteria (no primary fMRI data), so exclude.

Abstract indicates study of face-processing networks (social cognition) in temporal lobe epilepsy but does not specify imaging modality or presence of healthy control group. Insufficient abstract detail to confirm fMRI/healthy adults—include for full-text review.

Primary research using fMRI during social-cognitive tasks (reflection on self and friend) in healthy adult males; directly addresses social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria based on abstract.

The study reports fMRI during a Theory-of-Mind task in 47 patients with schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder and does not mention any healthy control group. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65). Not a review.

fMRI study of live social interaction (human-human vs human-robot) in a sample of 21 participants, assessing social processing (mentalizing, social motivation). Involves healthy adult participants and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract indicates study of social brain connectivity in schizophrenia but does not specify whether fMRI was conducted during a social task or whether healthy adult controls were included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of processing political beliefs, identifying dimensions tied to self-other processing and social decision-making, which fits social-related processing constructs. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult participants and task details.

Abstract reports neural (fMRI) investigation of empathy and mentalizing during social tasks in a large adult sample (N=178), assessing social cognition networks. It is an original empirical fMRI study in healthy adults and not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

The study enrolled only older adults (N=30, mean age 79). Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65; this sample falls outside that range. Abstract provides no younger adult group, so it does not meet the age criterion.

Abstract examines functional connectivity in ASD but does not state an fMRI social task or specify healthy adult participants; could be resting-state or include controls. Insufficient information in abstract to determine whether it meets the social-task and healthy adult criteria—include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining person-selective responses in anterior temporal lobes and social cognition; uses task encoding facts about people (social processing). No exclusion criteria met. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Abstract explicitly identifies the paper as a review rather than a primary fMRI study; it does not report original fMRI data on healthy adults. Exclude per exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an imitation task related to social interaction and social cognition (urge to imitate). Fits social-related processing constructs; not a review and meets age/group criteria.

Study involves pediatric stroke patients and resting-state fMRI (not a task-based social-processing fMRI) and does not include a healthy adult group aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the review criteria.

fMRI study examining Theory of Mind/social competition in healthy subjects using a social interaction task (human-human vs human-machine). Meets the review objective and inclusion criteria (social-related task during fMRI; healthy adult participants). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study measuring attractiveness comparisons—a form of perception/understanding of others (social processing) in human participants. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

Original fMRI study using social cognition tasks (face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM) performed during scanning; includes a healthy matched control group (13 HCs). Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages are not specified in abstract, participants are adults; study addresses social-related processing in healthy adults, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study reporting BOLD responses during tasks assessing animacy perception (a form of Perception and Understanding of Others/social perception) in human participants. Matches the review objective of social-related processing using fMRI. Abstract implies healthy adult subjects but does not specify ages; include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and other details.

fMRI study investigating neural processes of learning about others’ preferences (social cognition). It reports task-based fMRI during social-related processing. While participant health/age not specified in abstract, inclusion should proceed to full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.

The study used fMRI in awake dogs (non-human participants). The review objective requires functional MRI studies in healthy adult humans (ages 17–65). Because participants are animals, the study does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports neural responses to dynamic multimodal social/emotional stimuli in schizophrenia and depression, implying neuroimaging and likely inclusion of healthy controls; however it does not explicitly state fMRI nor participant ages. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm all inclusion criteria—include for full-text review.

The abstract describes ERP (EEG) research and theoretical review of emotion development and plasticity; it does not report fMRI scanning during a social-related task in healthy adults and appears to be a review/EEG-focused paper.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of social exclusion, punishment and forgiveness during social tasks (Cyberball, modified Dictator Game) in human participants; meets social-related processing and fMRI criteria. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining biological motion perception (a social-perception task) and reports both schizophrenia and healthy participant groups, meeting the fMRI + healthy adult criteria. Age range not specified; include for full-text verification.

Functional MRI was used during a social task (Cyberball social exclusion), which assesses social processing. The sample compares genetic homozygotes with no mention of psychiatric/neurological disorders, implying healthy adults. Meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm exact ages.

The study used fMRI while participants performed a social attribution/Theory of Mind task (perception/understanding of others) and included a healthy control group of adult women. It is an original study (not a review). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Event-related fMRI study of interpersonal resource conflict involving human vs. computer partners, probing social processing (sharing, social appraisal). Not a review; meets the social-task and fMRI criteria. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.
Participants were infants (3–7 months), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review; thus the study does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion.

The study used fMRI to assess neural responses during a social exclusion task (social-related processing) in 21 healthy adult volunteers. It is an original experimental study (not a review) and meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Functional MRI was used while participants read social vs non-social literary passages; the task probes social cognition and reports dmPFC activity mediating fiction-reading and social-cognition relation. Study involves human participants (presumably healthy adults) and is not a review. Age range not stated, but abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

Study includes a healthy adult group (ages 20-41) within the 17-65 range and used fMRI while participants performed a social-related task (discriminating social interactions from neutral movements). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used fMRI while participants made mental state judgments (social cognition), in a healthy adult sample (n=38). This directly fits the meta-analysis objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract/title indicate event-related fMRI to positive social stimuli (social processing), but it does not specify whether a healthy adult comparison group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review.

Task uses fMRI to investigate recall of relationship episodes involving self and others (social cognition: perception/understanding of self and others, affective/attachment dimensions). Sample: 35 healthy adults. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social processing including a healthy typically-developing control group, but participants described as 'youth' with no ages given. Age eligibility (17–65) unclear from abstract; include for full-text review to verify adult control ages.

fMRI study examining self-, mother-, and abstract-other (theory-of-mind) processing—these are social-related constructs (self/other understanding). Abstract implies healthy adult subjects and reports task-based BOLD activations. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages (17–65) and health status.

fMRI study examining emotional inferences from vocalizations and music, implicating social cognition/social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state a healthy sample, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study using the HCP social cognition paradigm (social processing). Includes a matched healthy control group (n=25), satisfying the requirement of at least one healthy adult group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Empirical fMRI study investigating neural responses to visually observed social interactions (interaction presence and type) in human participants. Uses task-based fMRI targeting social perception (pSTS/TPJ). Not a review/meta-analysis and appears to involve healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract discusses functional neuroimaging of social cognition and mentions simultaneous fMRI of two individuals, but provides no details on participants, ages (17–65), or task specifics. It is not clearly a systematic review/meta-analysis. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria from abstract alone — include for full-text review to assess participant health, ages, and task details.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment (n=17) where participants performed mentalising/theory-of-mind tasks (reading stories and answering questions), which is social-related processing. No clinical groups are mentioned and participants appear to be healthy adults. The abstract lacks explicit age ranges, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and participant health.

fMRI was performed while healthy adult participants (n=15) observed and rated virtual social interactions—a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). The sample appears to be healthy adults and the paper is an original fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text data extraction.

The fMRI task is a simple motor task examining cerebellar function in autism and controls; it does not involve social-related processing. Although healthy controls are included, the study does not meet the review objective of social processing.

fMRI study of mentalizing/social cognition (inferring others' preferences) in healthy adult participants (n=64). It reports task-based functional MRI related to self–other processing, matching inclusion criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social-cognition components (attentional and attributional biases), which fits the review’s topic. The abstract does not specify whether healthy adult participants were included; insufficient information to confirm exclusion, so include for full-text review to verify sample characteristics and ages.
fMRI study investigating voice recognition (a social communication/perception task) including matched healthy control participants (age 32), meeting inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

The article is a quantitative review/meta-analysis (ALE) of fMRI studies in clinical high-risk individuals, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not clearly report healthy adult social-task fMRI data.

Study used fMRI during a third-party punishment task (social processing: perception/understanding of others and moral responsibility). Participants are lay (healthy) adults; age range likely within 17–65. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study used fMRI during biological (body) motion perception, which maps onto social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). The paper reports a group of healthy matched controls alongside a patient group, satisfying the healthy adult group criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of relevance; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

Study used resting-state fMRI in children/adolescents with Autism Spectrum Disorder (no healthy adult group aged 17–65) and did not involve participants completing a social-related task. Does not meet population or task-based fMRI inclusion criteria.

Participants are children/adolescents (ASD and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. The study therefore does not include the target adult healthy sample for the meta-analysis.
Participants are children (N=24, mean age 10.2 years), which falls outside the required adult age range (17–65). Although it uses fMRI and social processing task, the age criterion is not met.
Participants are adolescents (age 16–17). The review requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65 (adults). The sample does not meet the adult age criterion, so exclude.
The study used resting-state fMRI (no task). It does not involve participants completing a social-related task, so it fails the primary inclusion criterion despite including healthy adult controls.

This paper is an ALE meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis/systematic review). The exclusion criteria specify excluding systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so this study should be excluded based on the abstract alone.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task-based social processing). Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; although healthy controls are present, no social task was performed. Therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.
fMRI study with healthy adult participants (mean/age 24) performing a social-related task (social regulation/handholding, affiliation/attachment). Meets age and task criteria and is not a review.

Participants are children/adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65). The study does not report fMRI of healthy adult participants performing a social-related task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study (n=164 healthy adults) using an interactive mentalizing (Prisoner’s Dilemma) task probing social cognition/attachment. The study used fMRI (with MEG) while participants viewed dynamic facial expressions, a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others/emotion recognition). The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and ages.

Original fMRI study examining social cognition (positivity motivation, perceptions of close vs non-close others) in human participants; involves affiliation/attachment constructs (romantic partner) and perception of others. No indication of patient groups or review article. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

Study used functional MRI during an interactive social task (self- and other-initiated joint/non-joint attention) in 24 healthy adult participants, addressing self- and other-processing constructs. No exclusion criteria are met; abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Human fMRI study investigating neural coding of dynamic social attention cues (head turns) in STS, addressing perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm that at least one group of healthy adults (17–65) was scanned.

fMRI measured brain activity in healthy adults while they viewed emotional social stimuli (movies). The task probes perception/understanding of others and social interaction networks (TPJ, mPFC, pSTS), matching the review’s social-related processing criteria. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include.

fMRI study of visual perspective-taking (social-cognitive task) with a matched healthy adult control group (20). Task assesses perception/understanding of others; not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Human fMRI study using a social task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in large sample of adult men and women; addresses social-affiliation/negative social interaction processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults and study is not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of face emotion processing (social cognition) comparing community groups high vs low in social anhedonia. Includes healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (emotion discrimination). Fits inclusion criteria; not a review. Full text can confirm ages if needed.

Abstract reports a single-case fMRI (n=1) with no group of healthy participants or participant ages reported. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults (age 17–65). Therefore the study does not meet the participant-group criterion.

Study used functional MRI while participants performed a social-affiliation task (shared viewing with a friend), involved healthy adult participants, and reports neural activity related to social sharing. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are described as adolescent boys (internet-addicted and healthy adolescents). The review requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65 (adults). fMRI study investigating guilt-related (social) processing and reporting activity in social cognition regions; meets the review’s domain. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65).

Abstract reports decoding of task fMRI including social cognition tasks using HCP data. fMRI was used to assess neural correlates of self/other social cognition and tasks involved social-representational processing; study includes a healthy control group. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of relevance; full text should be checked for participant ages and task details.

Abstract describes fMRI in patients with schizophrenia during acute episode and after recovery; no mention of a healthy control group or healthy adult participants. Therefore does not meet criterion of including at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65).

Task-based fMRI study of social (action-intention) processing that includes a typically developing healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.
Participants are school-age children (ages 9–13), outside the review's required healthy adult age range (17–65); therefore does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of action observation/execution investigating how observers process others' effort, which maps onto 'Perception and Understanding of Others' social processing. fMRI study investigates mentalizing and sensorimotor simulation during listening to literary fiction, addressing perception/understanding of others (social processing). Participants appear to be healthy adults, but ages/details aren’t specified in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm demographics and methods.

fMRI study of implicit facial emotion recognition—a social cognition task (Perception/Understanding of Others). Primary fMRI study where participants formed impressions of others (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). The abstract does not specify participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) demographics.

fMRI study of social cognition matching review objective. fMRI study examining empathy/social cognition (perception/understanding of others), fits the review objective. Abstract implies healthy adult participants though age not specified; insufficient detail on demographics warrants full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Real-time fMRI was used while volunteers played the ultimatum game, a social interaction task probing perception/decision about others. Participants are described as volunteers (healthy adults). This is a resting-state fMRI study with no task-based social processing; inclusion requires an fMRI scan while participants complete a social-related task. Although healthy controls are included, the absence of a social task excludes it.

Primary research fMRI study investigating neural responses to others' physical and emotional pain (Theory of Mind), i.e., perception/understanding of others. fMRI study of face processing (social perception/recognition) comparing an adult clinical case to control subjects; includes at least one group of healthy adult controls. Fits social-related processing domain (perception/understanding of others) and meets participant criteria. Not a review.

Original fMRI study using face-viewing paradigm (social perception/understanding of others) in a continuous sample including adults. Involves healthy participants and is not a review. Abstract does not state exact adult ages but refers to ‘adulthood,’ so include for full-text verification.

fMRI study investigating effects of social gaze on action control (social-related processing). Abstract indicates task manipulating social vs nonsocial cues; meets fMRI + social task criterion. Original fMRI study investigating empathy/affective responses to human and animal negative scenes—fits ‘perception and understanding of others’ social processing. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion; full text can confirm exact age range if needed.

The study reports human fMRI data on processing emotional facial expressions (social communication/perception of others), directly addressing the review objective. fMRI study examining brain responses to dynamic emotional facial expressions (social perception/understanding of others) in young adults; includes matched healthy control group (healthy participants within 17–65). fMRI study investigating neural processing of social dyadic interactions (perception/understanding of others). Reports task-based fMRI of self-evaluation (perception/understanding of self), a social-related construct; includes a matched healthy control group (adult participants) alongside patients; not a review or meta-analysis. fMRI study examining neural activity during general and contextual self-judgments (Perception and Understanding of Self), conducted in healthy adult participants across cultures; empirical study (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining neural responses to others' pain (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Uses task-based fMRI and reports effects of mortality salience on relevant brain regions. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a facial emotion processing task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) and included a matched healthy adult control group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Whole-brain fMRI was collected while participants performed a social task (viewing group members' faces) probing social cognition and valuation. Study appears to involve healthy adult social networks and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study using social-cognition tasks (Theory of Mind and empathy) in healthy adult participants (13 right-handed males, within 17–65). Task directly assesses perception/understanding of others; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers performing a social interaction task (matching-pennies game) involving perception/understanding of others (anthropomorphism, mind attribution). Primary fMRI study examining social cognition (empathy, Theory of Mind, self-other differentiation), matching review objective. fMRI study using point-light displays of human locomotion examines biological motion perception and cerebellum–STS connectivity, addressing perception/understanding of others (a social processing construct). Abstract does not specify participant health or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65).

Study uses task-based fMRI examining processing of human voices—a social communication/perception domain—so it aligns with the review objective. fMRI was used to measure cortical activation during social cognition tasks (theory of mind). The study includes a healthy control group of age-matched adults. It is an original fMRI study, not a review, and meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of healthy adult subjects passively watching realistic social interactions (social cognition/perception). Uses functional MRI during a social-related task, matches inclusion criteria and is not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a communicative/collaborative retrieval task; examines social-cognitive processes (mentalizing/theory of mind) and neural networks of understanding others, meeting the social-related processing and healthy adult criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI during negative emotion processing but does not state that the task/stimuli were social (e.g., social interaction, faces, attachment) or give participant details. The paper is explicitly a review article (neural systems approaches to the neurogenetics of autism) rather than an original fMRI study. It does not report functional MRI data from healthy adults performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract describes a pharmaco-fMRI study in healthy subjects performing a dyadic social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma), addressing social processing (mentalizing, reward, attention). Age range not specified in abstract but 'healthy subjects' and adult-focused journal make inclusion appropriate for full-text review.

Study reports fMRI during a social cognition task (false-belief ToM) with healthy adult comparison groups (480 adults). It examines social-related processing (Perception/Understanding of Others) and is primary research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.
Participants were non-human (dogs). The review requires fMRI studies of social processing in healthy human adults (age 17–65); this study used canine subjects, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study reports an fMRI experiment (Study II) investigating social interaction/gaze and social reward processing, includes a healthy control group alongside cocaine users, and uses a social-related task relevant to social communication/reward. Not a review/meta-analysis.

The abstract describes a meta-analysis across 12 fMRI studies rather than reporting primary fMRI data from participants. The exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so this study should be excluded.

fMRI study of dynamic happy facial expression processing with social interaction cues (social perception/communication). Includes a non-SPD (healthy) control group (n=14), likely adult sample; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study where healthy late-adolescent participants (ages 18–22) observed risk-taking versus safe actions—an implicit social-cognitive/emotional processing task (perception/understanding of others). Resting-state fMRI study in multiple sclerosis patients; no task-based social-processing paradigm and no healthy control group (ages 17-65) reported. Does not meet inclusion criteria of task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports fMRI studies of facial emotion perception (a social-related task). It is not a review/meta-analysis. fMRI study of irony comprehension (social communication) with an adult healthy control group (n=15). Task is social-related processing; includes healthy participants within target age range and is not a review.

Abstract reports task-related fMRI during a social perception task (plus resting-state), includes a healthy control group (n=21) of adults with no significant demographic differences, and is original research (not a review). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition in humans examining mirror neuron and mentalizing systems during social tasks; involves healthy adult participants; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in a sample of healthy adult women performing social perception tasks (judging social relationships from animations). This directly matches the review objective and inclusion criteria (functional MRI during social-related task; healthy participants). No exclusion criteria met.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adult participants engaging in social joint-action tasks (leading, following, mutual). Abstract describes an fMRI study probing social cognition (effects of emotion and social cognition on legal decision-making; perception/understanding of others) while participants read vignettes. fMRI study (34 participants) examining neural responses to social interactions during naturalistic movie viewing—directly addresses social processing (perception/understanding of others). Abstract focuses on emotional sentence attribution in schizophrenia but does not state whether healthy control participants were included or explicitly describe an fMRI task.
