fMRI study with 40 healthy volunteers viewing masked and unmasked facial emotions (social-affiliation relevant), assessing neural responses to others’ emotions—fits social-related processing. Participants are healthy adults and it is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

This study uses structural and functional MRI for ASD vs control classification (ABIDE I) and reports functional connectivity—no task-based fMRI of social-related processing is described, nor are healthy adult ages reported. Does not meet the social-task inclusion criterion.

fMRI was performed while participants completed a scanner-adapted Multifaceted Empathy Test (a social cognition/empathy task). Study included 50 age- and gender-matched healthy control participants alongside BPD patients (adult sample within typical age range). Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study with 20 adult participants examining neural responses to receiving empathic social comments (social communication/perception of others). Involves social-related task and reports neural activity; not a review and participants appear healthy. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating neural basis of bystander effect when witnessing an emergency—a social influence on helping behavior. Uses fMRI during a social-related task in humans; likely healthy adult participants. Abstract lacks explicit age/health details; include for full-text review to confirm sample.

fMRI study comparing neural responses to familiar vs unfamiliar faces (social perception/understanding of others). Includes an age-matched healthy control group. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.
This study is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis (a systematic review/meta-analysis), which directly meets the exclusion criterion excluding systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

fMRI study where participants viewed, imitated, and produced facial expressions and social hand gestures—clearly a social communication task. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and reports primary data (not a review). Abstract lacks explicit ages but meets inclusion constructs, so include for full-text review.

Event-related fMRI study probing evaluative judgments linked to self-referential processing and theory of mind (social cognition). Includes healthy young adult control group (age-matched). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports functional MRI recording during social judgments about people (age estimations and individuating food-preference inferences), directly addressing social cognition/perception of others. This meets the fMRI social-task inclusion criterion. Participant ages/health status are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm those details.

Participants are early adolescent girls (adolescence), not adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65; this study’s sample falls below the age range, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining honesty and trust (social cognition) during task-based scanning, fitting the review objective. Abstract does not state participant age/health, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study reports two fMRI experiments probing mentalizing/theory-of-mind (social cognition: perception and understanding of others), which fits the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy samples, but it is empirical (not a review). Include for full-text review to confirm participant health and age criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI during a facial imitate/observe task (social processing). Study includes people with and without severe mental illness, indicating a healthy control group of adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Sufficient information in abstract to meet inclusion criteria.
Participants are children (TD and ASD); no healthy adult group aged 17–65 is reported. Fails the age criterion for inclusion in the review.

fMRI study examining self vs others’ body-part processing in the extrastriate body area—addresses perception/understanding of self and others, a social-related construct. Abstract indicates fMRI adaptation paradigm and social-cognitive interpretation. Participant health and ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Abstract reports neuroimaging paradigms showing activity in STS, insula and amygdala during emotional prosody processing (social communication). The study includes a control (healthy) group compared to ASD participants, meeting the requirement for at least one healthy adult group. No exclusion criteria met.

Primary fMRI study where healthy participants performed impression-formation about other people (social-cognitive processing of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation if needed.

fMRI study of social decision-making from faces (affective social cognition). Compares males and females and contrasts ASD with typical individuals, implying inclusion of healthy adult participants. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text to confirm ages and extract data.

Functional MRI study examining social perception (faces/people vs scenes/objects), directly assessing social-related processing, and includes a healthy comparison group (n=14). Age range not specified in abstract, so full-text review should verify participants meet 17–65 criterion.

This is a narrative review of the neurobiology of social phobia, not an original fMRI study. The abstract does not report a functional MRI scan or human participants performing a social task; it only discusses fMRI as a future technology. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) using a naturalistic, video-based task (MASC), meeting the social-related task criterion. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; therefore include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult group (age 17–65).

Abstract does not specify whether an fMRI was used during a social-related task or whether healthy adult controls (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review.

fMRI study in normal adult volunteers performing social-related tasks (emotion identification and causal attribution of observed emotional behavior), which assesses perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used while participants considered selecting and sharing articles with other people—a social task involving self-related processing and perspective-taking. The study reports neural activity in valuation, self, and other-processing regions. Participants are healthy adults (no disorders reported). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing.

Study uses fMRI in healthy human participants to measure BOLD responses during observation and execution of actions after sensorimotor training. It probes mirror-system responses relevant to perception and understanding of others, a social-cognitive process. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (n=78) read and processed narratives appealing to "protected values," a social-cognitive task involving perception/understanding of others and value-based social processing. Fits inclusion criteria of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract does not specify whether healthy adult controls (age 17–65) were included or whether the fMRI involved a social-related task vs resting-state. Title suggests adults with autism and oxytocin administration, but information is insufficient to determine eligibility. Include for full-text review to verify participant groups and task details.

Participants are adolescents aged 11.1–15.5 years, which falls outside the review’s required healthy adult age range (17–65). Although an fMRI social task was used, the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

This is an fMRI study of social/affiliation processing (implicit personal space) using social vs non-social stimuli and oxytocin/placebo in human participants. It reports neural and behavioral effects relevant to social processing and is not a review. Participant health/age not explicitly stated but study design (double-blind OT in humans) implies healthy adult sample; thus meets inclusion for full-text review.

This is a conceptual primer/theoretical paper about brain-imaging principles and social neuroscience; the abstract describes no original fMRI study, participants, scanning procedures, or social task data. It does not meet the inclusion criterion of an fMRI study with human participants.

fMRI study with participants using compassion meditation and reappraisal while viewing film clips of people in distress — a social-affiliative task. Adult participants (expert practitioners) scanned; not a review. Meets social-processing and healthy adult criteria based on abstract.

Study uses fMRI during a social task (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) probing social cognition/understanding of others. It reports neural correlates in healthy adult participants (implied). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract gives sufficient evidence of relevance; include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health if needed.

This is a narrative review of neuroimaging in autism, not an original fMRI study. It summarizes structural and functional MRI findings in autistic patients rather than reporting an fMRI social-task experiment in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews and lacks required participant/sample and task details.

Participants are two young children with autism (case studies), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although fMRI was used on social stimuli, the sample does not include a healthy adult group, so it fails the participant/age inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (30 native Japanese speakers) performing a social-related task (communication vs description); investigates neural correlates of social communication and effects of anxiety/proficiency. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. No social-related task is described; thus it does not meet the requirement of fMRI during a social task despite including ASD and control groups.

Assesses facial emotion processing (social perception of others) comparing first-episode psychosis and healthy subjects, meeting the social-related task requirement and including a healthy adult group. Abstract implies neurofunctional assessment but does not explicitly state fMRI; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant ages/details.

The study used fMRI while human participants judged affective vocalisations, which fits social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). It reports neural responses in auditory/superior temporal regions. Participants are human (presumably healthy adults); no exclusion criteria (e.g., review/meta-analysis) apply. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study (N=37) where healthy adult participants performed a social-communication task (judging whether an actor addressed them). Addresses social communication construct and uses functional MRI. Age range not specified in abstract, but participants are adults; include for full-text review to confirm demographics and details.

Participants are adolescents (minor sample) rather than healthy adults aged 17–65; abstract gives no evidence that healthy participants fall within the target adult age range. Although fMRI and a social task (Cyberball) were used, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study examining neural responses to social (biological motion) stimuli, addressing perception/understanding of others; no exclusion criteria met. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

This is an fMRI experiment examining person perception and mentalising (social cognition), which aligns with the review objective. The abstract does not report participant health status or ages (17–65 requirement), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI task measuring amygdala responsiveness to social phobia–related verbal stimuli (social-related processing) and includes a matched healthy control group. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility and extract fMRI details.

Primary research using fMRI during a social-related task (valenced self/other referential processing; perception/understanding of self). Sample: 20 adult women (healthy group reported). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults; abstract provides sufficient information.

This is a structural MRI volumetric study (manual tracing of the fusiform gyrus) with no mention of functional MRI or an fMRI task. Although healthy controls are included, the study does not involve fMRI social-task paradigms required by the review.

fMRI study investigating social attributions (perception/understanding of others), in healthy adult participants implied; original research (not a review). Participant health/ages not explicitly stated in abstract—include for full-text verification.

Abstract explicitly describes an overview/overviewed history and introduces prior studies rather than reporting original primary fMRI data. It reads as a review/perspective with no methods or participant details; thus meets exclusion criterion for reviews.

fMRI study using emotional classification of audiovisual facial and vocal stimuli addresses social processing (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not report participant demographics or health status; include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult (17–65) sample and eligibility.

fMRI study examining self-referential recollection (conceptual and agentic self), which fits 'Perception and Understanding of Self' social-cognitive processing. Uses fMRI and behavioral tests, not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults; ages not specified—include for full-text verification.

This is an editorial/introduction to a special issue, not an original empirical fMRI study. Although it mentions fMRI methods and other empirical articles, the abstract contains no primary fMRI data on healthy adults and thus does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining social expectancy violations (warmth and competence), clearly a social-related task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status, so inclusion should be confirmed at full-text review. Include for full-text screening.

All participants are children (ages 7–13) with autism and age-matched typically developing children. The review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. Although fMRI of social stimuli was used, no healthy adult sample is included, so the study does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study assessing perception of social cues (fearful faces with direct vs averted gaze) — a social-related task (Perception and Understanding of Others). Includes a healthy adult control group (26 matched controls). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

The article appears to be a review (published in Sexual Medicine Reviews) summarizing neuroimaging studies of female sexual desire/HSDD rather than reporting original fMRI experiments. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses; additionally the abstract does not describe an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults.

Participants are children (ASD and typically developing); no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is included. Thus the study does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group.

fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social exchange processing in humans (Wason selection task). This directly addresses social-related processing and reports neural activations. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly, so full text should be checked, but inclusion is warranted for review screening.

Abstract describes social decision-making (ultimatum game) and neuronal networks, suggesting neuroimaging of social processing, but does not explicitly state use of functional MRI or report participant ages. Insufficient information to confirm fMRI and age criteria—include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Study uses fMRI during facial emotion processing (a social-related task). Abstract does not explicitly state presence of a healthy control group or participant ages; inclusion justified to retrieve full text to confirm healthy adult participants (17–65) and extract details.

The study used fMRI BOLD while healthy adults engaged with idiographic negative self-beliefs (autobiographical scripts), targeting perception/understanding of self—a social-related construct. Meets fMRI and healthy adult criteria; abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

23 healthy adults underwent fMRI while performing a visually based social judgment task (evaluating social dominance in faces), which is social-related processing (Perception/Understanding of Others). Study involves healthy participants aged within adult range and is an original fMRI study, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social cognition (recognition of happy faces) but does not specify whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm the presence of healthy participants; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study examining attentional orienting by gaze cues — a social-perception/communication task matching the review objective. Abstract implies experimental healthy participants but does not report ages or explicit health status; include for full-text review to confirm participant health and age eligibility.

Original fMRI study using healthy participants performing a social task (third-party punishment/mentalizing). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract lacks exact ages but meets inclusion; include for full-text to confirm age range and details.

The study reports fMRI data collected within a chronic traumatic brain injury population and does not indicate inclusion of any healthy adult control group (age 17–65). Because at least one healthy participant group is required, exclude based on abstract alone.

Abstract describes a review/synthesis of evidence (fMRI, TMS, EEG) on mirror neuron dysfunction in ASD rather than reporting an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It appears to be a review article and thus meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses; no primary data on healthy 17–65-year-old participants are presented.

Large-sample fMRI study (Human Connectome Project, n=787) reporting task-based activation for social processing in the same healthy adult cohort (ages within 17–65). It is primary empirical work (not a review) and meets the review’s social-task and healthy-participant inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI during altruistic (prosocial) choice, which is social-related processing. Methods include multivariate decoding of fMRI responses in healthy-sample cognitive neuroscience context. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/sample details.

Abstract describes an fMRI risk-taking task in adolescent girls but does not specify participant ages or clearly state the task was social-related. Inclusion criteria require healthy adults aged 17–65 and a social-related task; information is insufficient to confirm either. Include for full-text review to determine ages and whether the task meets the social-processing criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of mental state decoding (social cognition/perception of others) in healthy adult groups (native Japanese and white American participants). It involves functional MRI during a social-related task and is an original research article, not a review. Information in the abstract is sufficient to meet inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI study examining person perception and mentalizing (social-related processing) using human/robot avatars and belief manipulation. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit statement of healthy adults, so full-text should confirm demographics, but inclusion for full-text review is warranted.

Abstract reports an fMRI study (functional connectivity) in 30 healthy adult participants using a gaze-based social task (direct vs averted gaze) assessing action control—fits social processing constructs (perception/understanding of others). Not a review and meets age/health criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study analyzing brain responses to social auditory stimuli (one vs two people walking), fitting social processing objective. Abstract does not report participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample.

fMRI study of healthy adult groups (Naïve, Trained, Expert) observing demonstrator videos; examines social-cognitive processes (recognition of intentions, mentalizing, motor resonance), which fit review constructs. Abstract does not specify ages; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and task details.

The abstract describes an overview/review of molecular neuroimaging studies ('we provide an overview'), not a primary fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and provides no evidence of an original fMRI task in healthy adults.

Functional MRI was used during a social interaction task (virtual ball-tossing exclusion/inclusion). The study includes a healthy control group (matched for age and education), meeting the requirement of at least one healthy adult group. Not a review or meta-analysis. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing.

Abstract reports an fMRI study measuring hemodynamic responses to child stimuli in neural regions linked to social cognition, matching the social-processing objective. Participant age and health status are not specified in the abstract, so eligibility cannot be fully confirmed; include for full-text review to verify that at least one group is healthy adults aged 17–65.
fMRI study of piano-playing in patients with mild TBI; task is musical production (not a social-processing task) and no healthy adult participant group is reported. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

The study reports fMRI during speech repetition tasks (real words and pseudowords) focused on age-related changes in speech production and RT distributions. The abstract does not describe a social-related task or social communication processing (no affiliation/attachment, perception of self/others, or social interaction). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion of an fMRI social-related task.

Abstract reports an fMRI social approval task (social-related processing) and includes a healthy control group of adults alongside a clinical group; not a review or meta-analysis. Information is sufficient to meet inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The article is a review (states "We review"), not a primary fMRI study, and focuses on infants and macaques rather than fMRI in healthy adult humans (age 17-65). It therefore fails inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining gaze direction during face processing—a social communication/perception task involving humans. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies standard healthy adult sample; meets inclusion for fMRI social processing. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study reporting neural response in pSTS to stimuli depicting social interactions in humans; directly examines social perception. Likely involved healthy adult participants and is not a review. Fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a theoretical/review paper discussing explanations of mirror-touch synesthesia and prior fMRI evidence; it does not report an original fMRI study, participant groups, or methods. Therefore it does not meet inclusion of an fMRI study in healthy adults and should be excluded.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of prosodic (social-communication) processing but does not state whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included or provide participant ages. Task is social-related, but insufficient info to confirm healthy adult group—include for full-text review.

fMRI study of theory-of-mind/intention (social-related processing) with healthy control group compared to patients; adults likely within 17–65; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full review.

All participants described are children (including 3 normal children and 2 autistic/Asperger children). The review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65; age criterion not met despite fMRI social task.

fMRI study of social communication (L2) involving communicative speech tasks in 30 native Japanese speakers (healthy adults). Addresses social communication and neural correlates, fits review objective; not a review or meta-analysis. Include for full-text review.

Original fMRI study using an empathy-for-pain social task assessing empathic brain responses; includes a control (healthy) participant group (adults) and addresses social-related processing. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is a review article summarizing psychopharmacological and fMRI research rather than a primary fMRI study with healthy participants performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Original fMRI study examining social tasks (eye gaze, face processing, directional cuing) that included neurotypical (healthy) control participants. Fits review objective of social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults; abstract does not state ages, so full text should be checked for age range.

Abstract reports two independent fMRI experiments assessing emotional egocentricity bias during empathic judgments (a social-cognitive task) in humans, identifying rSMG activation; not a review/meta-analysis. Participant sample likely healthy adults. Fits inclusion: functional MRI during social-related task in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants investigating perception of social stimuli (two bodies facing vs nonfacing). This is a social-perception task (Perception and Understanding of Others) and meets the inclusion criteria; not a review.

fMRI study of audiovisual speech processing (social communication) that includes an age- and gender-matched healthy control group (adults). Task involves social communication (speech perception). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria.

Study addresses social cognition constructs (theory of mind, empathy) and title indicates functional brain correlates (likely fMRI). Abstract does not specify whether healthy control group (age 17-65) was included or details of task-based fMRI. Insufficient information to confirm eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Study used structural MRI covariance analysis, not functional MRI during social tasks. The meta-analysis requires fMRI of participants performing social-related tasks; thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a task with social stimuli (neutral faces) and reports social-processing activations (superior temporal sulcus), aligning with the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit statement that sample were healthy adults; however, no exclusion criteria are met. Insufficient demographic detail means full-text is needed to confirm health/age eligibility, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study of neural responses to observed actions (perception/understanding of others), which fits social-related processing. Abstract reports subjects viewed actions but does not specify ages or health status; include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and health criteria.

fMRI study includes social-related tasks (action observation/execution and action understanding) probing mirror neuron system and theory of mind; includes a healthy control group. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in adults.
fMRI (BOLD) used while participants rated faces for trustworthiness (a social perception task). Includes a healthy control group (adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion task) in healthy participants. However participants are described as ‘male adolescents’ with no ages reported, so it is unclear if they meet the 17–65 age criterion. Abstract is not a review. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study examining neural representation of heard actions and action understanding (mirror system), which fits 'Perception and Understanding of Others' social processing. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult group (17–65) and other eligibility details.

Abstract describes use of dyadic fMRI (dfMRI) and reports experimental BOLD results related to face-to-face social interaction and networks (empathy, mentalization, DMN). It does not specify participant characteristics or exact task; insufficient detail to confirm healthy adult sample, so include for full-text review to assess eligibility.

Study used resting-state fMRI correlated with ToM behavioral scores rather than a task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Although healthy controls were included, it does not meet the requirement of functional MRI acquired while participants performed a social task.

Abstract addresses self- and other-reflection, a social-related cognitive process likely investigated with brain imaging. However the abstract does not specify fMRI modality nor whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient detail to exclude; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI usage and healthy participant inclusion.

Abstract is a field overview/perspective discussing social neuroscience and fMRI literature, not an original fMRI study with human participants. It appears to be a review; exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses applies. Insufficient indication of an empirical fMRI experiment in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 22 healthy adult males performing allocentric social hierarchy and social alliance judgments—tasks clearly probe social processing (perception/understanding of others). Functional MRI was acquired during task; sample age fits 17–65 and includes healthy participants. Not a review or meta-analysis. Therefore meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract does not report use of functional MRI. It describes spectral-density analysis and temporally precise interpersonal cerebral coherence, consistent with electrophysiological methods (MEG/EEG) rather than fMRI. Therefore it does not meet the fMRI requirement.

Study investigates executive dysfunction in autism spectrum disorder using network/hub architecture, not social-related processing. Abstract does not indicate an fMRI social task or the presence of a healthy adult control group (ages 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a social interaction task (reaction-time competition with opponents) that elicits reactive aggression; examines neural processing during decision/outcome phases—meets social-related processing and fMRI criteria. Abstract does not state participant health or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Participants are described as 'youth' (children/adolescents) including clinical DBD group and typically developing youth; no healthy adult (age 17–65) sample. Does not meet the age requirement for inclusion.

fMRI study examining perception of emotions in dynamic crowds—clearly a social-related processing task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not report participant health status or ages; no exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study involving affective creativity/cognitive reappraisal and mentions recruitment of default-mode regions implicated in social cognition. Abstract does not clearly state the task is explicitly social nor provide full participant details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI while participants performed a social-related task. Inclusion requires a functional MRI scan during a social task; therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports functional MRI in volunteers performing an odour-based social evaluation task (recognition/preference of self vs non-self MHC peptides). Task relates to social processing (perception/understanding of self and social communication) and participants are healthy volunteers, meeting inclusion criteria.

Study used simultaneous fMRI (with PET) to probe mothers’ brain responses to their infants and measured connectivity within a social-affiliation network. Participants are adult mothers (healthy adult group) performing an affiliation/attachment task, meeting inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

The study used fMRI to measure neural representations of others’ mental states (social cognition/perception of others), fitting the review’s social-processing objective. It reports human (male and female) participants with no indication of psychiatric/neurological disorders and is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review). The abstract does not specify participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

The study uses fMRI during a memory recognition/decision-making task and investigates memory control networks, not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, or perception of self/others). Thus it does not meet the review’s social-processing inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of altruistic decision-making probing social cognitive processes (empathy, perspective taking, attention) in human participants; reports neural responses during tasks and links to behavior. Appears to use healthy adult subjects and is an original research article, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used while healthy adult subjects performed social-related tasks (evaluating faces after learning cooperators vs defectors via Prisoner’s Dilemma). The study probes perception/understanding of others and social cognition; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract discusses neuroscience of ecstatic epilepsy and related phenomena, likely a review/case series in patient populations; does not report an fMRI task of social-related processing in healthy adults. Appears not to meet inclusion criteria.

This appears to be a narrative review summarizing fMRI studies in typical and autistic participants; the abstract does not report original fMRI methods/results for a specific social task in healthy adults. Inclusion cannot be determined from the abstract alone, so include for full-text review to verify presence of primary fMRI data in healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=26) investigating empathy for pain—a social cognitive process (perception/understanding of others). Participants completed fMRI tasks observing human/robot agents; fits inclusion criteria and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Abstract reports a mega-analysis of fMRI studies in which participants considered others' mental states (social cognition/perception of others), fitting the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult group and eligibility.
Participants are children (mean age ~10 years). The meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65; no adult group is reported in the abstract.

fMRI study using naturalistic dynamic face videos examining attention to social information (emotional valence and age). Investigates perception/understanding of others in face-responsive cortex; abstract implies typical healthy participants. No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract describes an fMRI study where healthy young adult participants (non-clinical sample of 20 males) completed social/empathic processing tasks using first-person video scenarios. This directly matches the review objective and inclusion criteria (functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study where participants listened to voices and performed identity and emotion recognition — a social-perception (Perception and Understanding of Others) task. Includes a group of sighted healthy adults (n=15). Abstract does not report age range; include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 17–65 age criterion.

Event-related fMRI was collected while participants performed a mind-perception (social-cognitive) task; study reports neural correlates of social attention (gaze-cueing). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original fMRI study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Not a task-based fMRI study of social processing (uses resting-state and structural measures). Participants are boys with mean ages ~11–12 (range includes children/adolescents), not a healthy adult group aged 17–65.

Abstract reports fMRI during an emotional task and includes a healthy control group (n=25, likely adults). While it does not explicitly state a social-related task, emotional processing is potentially relevant to social cognition; abstract lacks sufficient detail to confirm exclusion. Include for full-text review to determine if task fits social-related constructs.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a social-related task, and participants were exclusively patients with Major Depressive Disorder (no healthy adult group). Thus it does not meet the requirement of task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social-related paradigm. Inclusion requires functional MRI while participants complete a social-related task; although healthy controls are included, the absence of an active social task means it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This article is a narrative review (states 'In this review...') summarizing neurobiological findings in adolescents rather than reporting original fMRI data in human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion: systematic review/meta-analysis; no primary fMRI study of healthy adults.

fMRI-pupillometry study examining how pupil mimicry during social interactions modulates trust and recruits theory-of-mind regions. This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing in (presumably) healthy adults and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task in healthy adults.

fMRI experiment reports neural responses to disfigured faces—clearly a social-perception task (Perception and Understanding of Others). The study includes healthy participants (behavioral and fMRI samples), though exact ages not stated; abstract provides sufficient evidence of social-related fMRI to warrant full-text review to confirm participant ages and health.

All participants were described as entering psychotherapy for depression and/or anxiety; the abstract does not report any healthy adult control group. This fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65).

Block-design fMRI measured neural responses to perception of facial expressions (social communication/perception of others). Meets the review objective of fMRI studies of social processing. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health, so include for full-text to confirm demographics and eligibility.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and involved young children (ages 3–7) including an ASD group; it does not include healthy adult participants (17–65) performing a social task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Primary human fMRI study using the Prisoner’s Dilemma social interaction task reporting neural responses (ventral tegmental area, amygdala) to cooperative/non-cooperative interactions. Appears to involve healthy adult men and women. Not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health details.

fMRI study of healthy participants performing social decision-making scenarios (regret, disappointment) with young adults included. It assesses social-related processing (social-cognition regions) and is not a review. Sufficient abstract information supports inclusion for full-text review.

Study uses task-based 3T fMRI (BOLD) during humorous-cartoon processing, a form of social cognition/social communication. Sample: 29 healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults) and is not a review.

This is a protocol for a behavioral resilience training for individuals with psychotic disorder; abstract does not mention any fMRI data or social-processing fMRI tasks, and participants are patients not healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of communicative intention recognition (a social-communication task). It appears to involve healthy participants, but participant ages/health status are not specified in the abstract. Because it meets the fMRI + social processing criterion and lacks clear exclusion info, include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics.

fMRI study where healthy participants (N=50 across two studies) retrieved biographical/person knowledge—clearly social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not stated in abstract, so include for full-text verification.

Abstract reports an fMRI study examining simulation of others’ decisions—a clear social cognition task. It likely involves healthy human participants but the abstract does not state ages/health explicitly. Include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=60) performing an explicit social-attitude task (control of trust/distrust toward others). Directly examines social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) and meets age/participant criteria; not a review.

The study used fMRI (multivoxel pattern analysis) during an audio-visual social-norm inference task requiring participants to judge appropriateness of emotional vocalizations in context (social-related processing). Event-related fMRI study examining processing of angry voice prosody—a social communication task relevant to social cognition. Abstract reports brain responses and attention modulation but does not specify participant health status or ages. Meets task criterion; include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult participants (ages 17–65) and other eligibility details.

The study reports an fMRI scan during a Theory of Mind task (social cognition) and includes a healthy adult control group (25 age- and gender-matched controls). Participants are adults (within 17–65). It is an original research article, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of gesture-speech integration, a social communication task. Includes at least two healthy adult groups (n=19; n=17) alongside patients, meeting the age/group criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to confirm relevance to social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was used with tasks including social-distance trials (friends vs acquaintances), directly addressing social processing. Abstract implies human participants likely healthy adults. Age/health not specified; per protocol, include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics.

fMRI study using the Trust Game (social decision-making/perception of others), reports neural activations in healthy-seeming Machiavellian participants. Not a review. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract—include for full-text verification.

fMRI study of emotional facial expression processing (social communication/perception of others) in 12 healthy subjects; meets requirement of functional MRI during a social-related task and includes healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examines audiovisual integration of human faces and non-verbal vocalizations—a social communication/perception task relevant to review. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages (17–65), so full text is needed to confirm inclusion criteria are met.

Study uses fMRI during a social-related Theory of Mind (mentalizing) task (visual jokes). Abstract reports a matched healthy control group (n=13), indicating at least one healthy adult group. Human fMRI study examining how learning about others’ values alters self-value representations in mPFC—clearly a social processing task. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one group of healthy adults (17–65).

Event-related fMRI was performed in 14 healthy adults (mean age 29±6) while they viewed and processed others' emotional facial expressions—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). fMRI study of observation and mental imagery of face and limb movements; authors explicitly discuss limb gesture processing as part of human social communication, aligning with the 'Social Communication' construct. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

Study examines resting-state functional connectivity in cocaine-dependent individuals, not task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. No social-related task and focuses on a clinical group, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study includes a social-related task (theory-of-mind/social attribution). Abstract does not specify that participants were healthy adults or their ages; insufficient information to confirm eligibility, so include for full-text review to verify participant health/age.

fMRI study investigating social-communication-related processing (vitality forms in speech and actions). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly, but likely healthy adults; insufficient detail to confirm age range, so include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics.

fMRI study of direct and reflected self-appraisals (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related task, including a healthy adult participant group aged 23–30 (within 17–65). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a social cognition task (implicit false-belief/Theory of Mind) with participants watching Sally–Anne movies; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults aged 17–65.

Functional MRI study of emotional facial expression processing (social perception of others), which is a social-related task; includes a healthy adult control group (mean age 27, within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The fMRI task involved viewing erotic pictures/videos to probe sexual desire (ventral striatum activity). The abstract reports fMRI data including a 'social cognition' task domain, meeting the review objective of social-related processing. Participant health status and age range are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65).

This article is itself a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation of 125 fMRI studies). It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded based on the abstract.

fMRI study using an interactive social exclusion task (ball-toss game) probing social cognition/affiliation; no exclusion criteria met. Abstract does not state participant age/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets age/healthy criteria.

fMRI study with human participants performing collaborative and competitive tasks assessing social motivation/processing; targets social interaction constructs (collaboration/competition). Abstract implies healthy adult participants and is an original research article (not a review). Fits inclusion criteria; minor uncertainty only because exact ages/health status not specified in abstract.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=37) performing a social-evaluative task (watching approving/disapproving social videos). Addresses social processing constructs; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI findings (pre-genual ACC, dorsomedial frontal area 9) during cooperative and competitive tasks involving self- and other-related processing—a social cognitive task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Participant health/age not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

The study used resting-state fMRI to parcellate lateral frontal cortex and did not involve a task-based fMRI paradigm of social-related processing in healthy adults. It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring task-based social processing.
The paper is a review of neuroimaging literature (not an original fMRI study with participants). It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and thus should be excluded.

Abstract describes an fMRI experiment in which participants attributed awareness to a cartoon face (a social attribution task). Age range not specified in abstract, so moderate confidence; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics.

Hyperscanning fMRI study examines mutual gaze and joint attention—clearly a social-processing task relevant to perception/understanding of others/social communication. Not a review. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Functional MRI was performed during an explicit emotion-recognition task (face processing), which is social perception/understanding of others, in a sample of healthy young adult males (meets age and healthy participant criteria). This is an original fMRI study, not a review.

Original functional MRI experiment investigating social cognition (control of shared representations, self-other distinction, mental state attribution) with reported brain activations (aFMC, TPJ). Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages not specified in abstract, it reports an fMRI experiment likely with healthy adults; meets review objective of social-related fMRI studies.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of abstract vs concrete mindsets in social cognition; likely involves social-related processing and uses fMRI in (presumably) healthy adults. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm sample and specifics.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI while participants completed a social-related task. fMRI study using human-related auditory stimuli (footsteps) and reports involvement of ‘social cognition’ area (pSTS), indicating social-related processing. Abstract lacks explicit participant health/age details; unclear from abstract alone, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study probing social appraisal (judging liking of emotional faces), addressing perception/understanding of others; includes a healthy adult control group (n=21). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition in adults: healthy participants viewed images of social groups while undergoing functional MRI, examining neural responses (mPFC, insula, amygdala) related to perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in young healthy adults performing tasks with a social manipulation (peer observation). Examines social-related processing/connectivity (AIC–vmPFC) during peer observation, meeting inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining neural responses to emotional speech prosody (a social communication task) in a sample of healthy adult participants; directly addresses social-related processing and is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

Primary data fMRI study measuring maternal neural responses to infant cry (affiliation/attachment social processing) in a sample of healthy adult mothers; meets task-based fMRI and participant-age criteria and is not a review.

All participants were non-treatment-seeking individuals with alcohol use disorder (no healthy control group), so the study lacks a healthy adult sample aged 17–65. Additionally, reported age range extends to 66, exceeding the 65-year limit.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in neurologically normal participants performing social cognition tasks (reasoning about others’ mental states). Age range not specified but 'neurologically normal participants' implies healthy adults; include for full-text review if age needs confirmation.

This paper is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults. The exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore it should be excluded despite addressing social processing.

fMRI was used while participants viewed a moral dilemma involving kin vs non-kin, addressing social cognition (moral/emotional/mentalizing processes). The study involves human subjects (adults implied) and meets the social-related task criterion. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of relevance; include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health.

This study used resting-state fMRI in toddlers with ASD (a clinical pediatric sample) and identified an ASD subtype; it did not involve a task-based social processing fMRI or include healthy adults (age 17-65). Therefore it does not meet the review’s task-based fMRI or adult healthy participant criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI connectivity study (no social task performed during scanning). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults, which is not met based on the abstract.

Abstract addresses visual personal familiarity (social/person recognition) but does not specify whether a functional MRI was used or whether a healthy adult control group (ages 17–65) was included. Key inclusion criteria are unclear, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This is a review/synthesis article discussing conceptual, lesion, and fMRI literature on emotion perception and theory of mind rather than reporting original fMRI data collected in healthy adult participants. Study examines neural correlates of emotional prosody comprehension (social communication/perception of others), likely using fMRI. Abstract does not explicitly report imaging modality or participant characteristics/age range. Insufficient methodological detail in abstract to confirm all inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study of interpersonal manual touch (human delivering touch) in healthy adult participants; task involves social/affiliative tactile interaction and examines brain networks potentially supporting social interaction. This is a narrative review/chapter summarizing evidence (postmortem, structural MRI, fMRI) across neurodevelopmental disorders, not an original fMRI study of healthy adults performing a social-related task; no participant sample or task data provided.
The article is a quantitative meta-analysis of neuroimaging studies (fMRI/PET). The exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses; therefore it should be excluded.

Abstract reports training-induced changes in neural activation and connectivity (e.g., DLPFC, nucleus accumbens) in healthy adults in response to others' suffering — indicating task-based functional neuroimaging of social-related processing. Not a review. Meets age/health criteria as 'healthy adults.' Therefore include for full-text review.

This is a review/book chapter focusing on developmental social neuroscience and adolescents, not a primary fMRI study in healthy adults. It does not report fMRI methods or adult (17–65) healthy participants and meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Abstract examines neural responses (mentalizing) to emotionally salient eye expressions in adults with Tourette syndrome and healthy controls, addressing social cognition. However the abstract does not explicitly state use of fMRI; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant ages/healthy group.

fMRI study using a social task (Trust Game) with healthy participants, but sample is described as 'adolescence' and no ages are reported. Meta-analysis requires healthy adults (17–65). Abstract insufficient to determine age eligibility, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages.

Functional MRI study examining self- and other-related social cognition (personality trait judgments about self vs friend) with BOLD measures in mrPFC. Appears to involve healthy human participants and directly addresses social processing constructs; not a review.

The study examines recognition memory and emotion-related fMRI repetition effects (negative/positive/neutral visual stimuli) and functional connectivity, not social cognition or social-related tasks (affiliation, communication, perception of self/others). fMRI study in healthy adult subjects investigating perception/understanding of others’ actions and associated mentalizing network activity—fits social cognition constructs (perception/understanding of others). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

This paper is an activation likelihood estimation (ALE) meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis/systematic review). The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded based on the abstract alone.
This article is a coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies (30 articles). The exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses; thus it should be excluded.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants (21 male adults) performed a social perception task (rating naturalness of dyadic nonverbal interactions), targeting perception and understanding of others. fMRI study investigating mentalizing (social cognition) about individuals and groups; participants performed social-related tasks during functional MRI. No indication of clinical populations; fits healthy adult sample and review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI task contrasts anticipation of touching an animate (human) vs inanimate target—socially relevant processing (perception/understanding of others). Includes healthy volunteers. Abstract lacks participant age details, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and other eligibility; not a review.

Participants are preschool-aged children with autism spectrum disorder (not healthy adults aged 17–65). The study examines amygdala functional connectivity in young children, not an fMRI social-task in healthy adult participants, so it does not meet inclusion.

fMRI study with 19 healthy adult participants (within 17–65) performing a social-related task (Trust Game) examining neural correlates of reciprocity. Not a review/meta-analysis and fits inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract describes qualitative social-science work (focus group and questionnaire) with adolescents and does not report any functional MRI data or fMRI task of social processing. fMRI study using the cyberball social-inclusion paradigm (a social processing task) and includes a healthy control group (n=17). Abstract describes a language semantic task in patients with schizophrenia and does not state inclusion of healthy adults or that the task is social-related. Insufficient information to determine if it meets social-processing and healthy-participant criteria; include for full-text review.

Participants are children/adolescents (not within required 17–65 adult range) and the task involves basic auditory/visual perceptual judgments, not social-related processing. Therefore it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Uses fMRI to examine effects of hypnotic suggestion on pain in healthy suggestible adults. Original fMRI study investigating neural responses to conspecific disgust facial expressions—clearly a social-perception/understanding task. fMRI study investigating neural responses during a social task (gains for self, best friend, disliked other) in healthy participants; directly addresses social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text to confirm participants are within 17–65.

Abstract reports an image-guided rTMS study creating a ‘virtual lesion’ over the right IPL; no functional MRI scanning is described. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Exclude based on absence of fMRI.

fMRI study of social processing (gaze shifts, joint attention) directly matches the review objective. Abstract reports neural and behavioral responses but does not specify participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

7T fMRI study examining attachment-related (social/affiliation) processing during auditory narratives in healthy participants (fMRI subset n=23). fMRI experiment examining processing of biological motion and social intentions (mirror and mentalizing systems) during a social-perception task (judging facing direction); appears to involve healthy participants. fMRI study in healthy adult subjects examining mental state attribution (understanding intentions) when listening to perceived human vs computer-generated music; directly assesses social-related processing (theory of mind). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Event-related fMRI study investigating gender perception from faces, which is a social perception task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract reports primary data in (presumably) healthy participants and is not a review. Age range not specified—include for full-text to confirm participant ages and health status.

Abstract reports fMRI in individuals with PAX6 mutation during verbal fluency and nonsense sentence completion, but tasks are not clearly social-related per the review constructs; the abstract also does not specify whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Participants are children with autism spectrum disorder; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group. Study does not include healthy adult participants, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of reciprocity using the Trust Game—a social processing task. Reports brain activations (aMPFC, rTPJ, ACC, insula, dlPFC). This fMRI study reports neural activation while participants processed human action sentences (concrete vs. abstract), implicating networks related to action understanding (perception/understanding of others). This publication is an activation likelihood estimation (ALE) meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study. Abstract reports an fMRI study targeting posterior STS using dynamic facial expressions (a social-related face perception task) and neurofeedback. Empirical fMRI study in healthy participants examining mentalizing, empathy, and prosocial behavior (social cognition/perception of others). fMRI study of social evaluation (in-group/out-group politicians) addressing social cognition processes. Abstract implies human participants and aligns with social-related task. fMRI study of social cognition (representation of others’ actions/interactions) in 29 healthy adult participants; directly addresses perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Sufficiently meets the inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Adults completed an fMRI paradigm measuring brain response to fearful faces (social-related processing). The study includes a healthy control group of adult males matched for age/IQ, meeting the 17–65 criterion. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text extraction.

Abstract does not state whether fMRI was used or whether a healthy control group (ages 17–65) was included; focus is on first-episode schizophrenia but methods are unclear. Study sample are children with ASD and age-matched typically developing children (not healthy adults aged 17–65). fMRI study examining empathy for pain—a social-processing task—and resulting prosocial behavior in human participants, matching the review objective. fMRI study where participants made social evaluations of people—falls under perception/understanding of others/social processing. fMRI study of vocal emotion recognition (social processing). However sample is ages 8–19 and the abstract does not specify a distinct healthy adult (17–65) group; unclear whether inclusion age criterion is met. Include for full-text review to verify participant ages and grouping.

fMRI study where participants made judgments about social categories/stereotypes—task clearly involves social cognition (understanding others). Appears to use healthy adult participants; not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

Abstract examines social-cognitive brain function during visual perspective-taking (a social task) but does not explicitly state fMRI use or presence of a healthy control group. Abstract reports fMRI activation (anterior insula, prefrontal cortex, ventral striatum) during a social interaction task (emotion alignment between paired participants). Likely healthy adult sample; addresses social processing constructs. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social feedback (social inclusion/exclusion), matching the review objective. This is a structural MRI study (cortical thickness and structural covariance) in autism vs controls, not a functional MRI study during a social-related task in healthy adults. Does not meet fMRI nor task-based social processing criteria.

fMRI experiment probing neural mechanisms of persuasion/attitude change—clearly social-related processing (social influence, re-evaluation of objects via expert). Not a review. fMRI study of facial emotion recognition (social processing) including a neurotypical control group of adults. Task assesses perception/understanding of others; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

Abstract reports an independent fMRI study comparing social vs. non-social image appraisal with ROI BOLD analyses, directly addressing social processing in humans. fMRI studies of perception of dynamic audio-visual emotional cues (social-emotional processing) fit the review objective. fMRI study modeling neural representations of sentence content that includes factors differentiating social interactions versus physical state changes. Abstract reports neural activation (somatosensory cortices, amygdala, hippocampus, inferior PFC) associated with tactile priming affecting social-judgment tasks, indicating an fMRI study of social processing. This is a narrative review of fNIRS studies in children and infants with Autism Spectrum Disorder, not an original functional MRI study in healthy adults. It is a review article (excluded) and does not meet the fMRI/healthy adult inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult groups (omnivores, vegetarians, vegans) performing observation of mouth actions—a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others and action observation/execution matching. Abstract is too brief to confirm that a functional MRI was used or that participants included healthy adults aged 17–65. Abstract reports an fMRI study using a socio-emotional social preference task probing social evaluation/processing. fMRI study of social competition vs noncompetitive learning in human participants, examining mPFC and precuneus activation related to social processing and task distraction. Appears to involve healthy adult participants; meets inclusion criteria and does not meet any exclusion criteria.

This study reports resting-state brain activity in bvFTD patients rather than task-based fMRI of social processing, and the abstract does not indicate inclusion of healthy adult participants. Study examines maturational/developmental changes in face specialization (typical development), implying child/adolescent samples rather than healthy adults 17–65. Abstract does not clearly report an fMRI social-task in adults. Therefore it does not meet the population criterion for inclusion.

fMRI study of agency inferences (perception/understanding of self), includes a healthy adult control group (31 controls). Task is social-related (self-agency), not a review, and meets inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

Event-related fMRI study of self-face recognition (perception/understanding of self), involving healthy normal adult participants (ten right-handed subjects). Not a review/meta-analysis. fMRI study with 16 healthy adult volunteers performing judgments of pride and joy—tasks probing social/self-conscious emotion and theory-of-mind processes. fMRI study in healthy participants assessing social-concept processing (judging meaning relatedness of social concepts). Fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of task-based fMRI in humans.

Event-related fMRI study examining how the anterior cingulate cortex processes outcomes of others' decisions (social cognition/perception of others). Human scanned subjects implied; not a review. fMRI study presenting dynamic facial expressions (onset/offset of happy and angry faces) probing emotional/social communication processing; likely healthy adult participants; meets social-related task criterion and uses functional MRI. Study reports an fMRI task involving face perception/recognition (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. This is an fMRI study examining amygdala responses to masked fearful eyes, a social-perception task (processing others’ emotional cues). fMRI study using the Reading the Mind in the Eyes task (social cognition). Study reports an fMRI social-cognitive task (neutral facial-expression processing) in healthy participants (n≈73–74), addressing perception/understanding of others. Meets review focus on social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract—include for full-text to confirm ages and other details.

This study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social-processing paradigm. Inclusion requires functional MRI collected while participants completed a social-related task; although healthy controls were included, the lack of task-based social fMRI excludes it.

fMRI study using a speed-dating paradigm where participants were scanned while receiving social feedback (romantic interest or rejection). This investigates social processes (affiliation/mentalizing, perception of others) in human participants and is not a review.

Abstract discusses fMRI studies of deception and social cognition but appears to be a narrative summary of multiple studies rather than reporting primary data.
