fMRI study examining changeable aspects of faces and social communication/perception of others—fits review objective. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages; insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify participants meet healthy adult (17–65) requirement.

Participants are preterm infants (31+6 to 36+3 weeks PMA), not healthy adults (17–65). The fMRI task examines somatosensory/sensorimotor mapping, not social-related processing. Therefore it does not meet the population or outcome criteria.
The abstract explicitly describes a meta-analysis of 33 fMRI studies (Activation Likelihood Estimation). Per the exclusion criteria, systematic reviews or meta-analyses are excluded.

fMRI study examining social perception/emotion (observing violent interactions) which matches the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17-65), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with 34 healthy participants performing an empathic accuracy task (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so full text needed to confirm ages 17–65; include for full-text review.

Participants are children (ages 10–15), outside the required adult range (17–65). The task is passive auditory change detection (frequency-deviant and novel sounds), not a social-related processing task. Does not meet population or task inclusion criteria.

This is a review article summarizing research (2005–2010), not a primary fMRI study. It is a systematic/narrative review, which meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses; abstract does not report original fMRI data from healthy adults performing social-related tasks.

fMRI was used while participants completed the Reading-the-Mind-in-the-Eyes Task (a social cognition/Theory of Mind task), and the sample includes a healthy non-offender control group. The study is empirical (not a review) and thus meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

Study 2 reports fMRI activation while participants viewed sexualized and clothed human targets, examining mental-state attribution (a social-cognitive process). Participants are healthy adults (male and female). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits the inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study uses fMRI during a social trust task and includes a healthy control group, but controls are aged 13–19 (adolescents). Unclear whether healthy participants meet the adult 17–65 criterion from abstract alone; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports functional MRI during a social closeness task (photos of friends vs unknown people), targeting social cognition. Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is empirical (VBM and fMRI), not a review. Thus meets inclusion for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study measuring interpersonal space (a social/affiliation task) with reported imaging results. The study used a healthy adult sample (double-blind placebo-controlled) and examines social processing regions. Age range not specified in abstract, but it meets the primary inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI paradigm using theory-of-mind (social cognition) tasks and includes a healthy control group (n=14). This meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria apparent. Age not specified but participants appear adult.

Event-related fMRI study in healthy human subjects performing a social communication task (gaze and pointing/following directional cues), directly fits the review objective. No exclusion criteria met. Participant ages are not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

Participants are children aged 3–5 (not adults 17–65) and the study used resting-state fMRI to examine intrinsic connectivity, not a task-based social processing fMRI. Therefore it does not meet the population or task criteria for inclusion.

Participants are Latin-American preadolescents (children), not adults. Meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65. Although the study used fMRI with a social cognition task, the age criterion is not met, so exclude.

fMRI study examining theory-of-mind (cooperation vs deception) in healthy volunteers performing social-cognitive tasks. This fits the review objective (social processing via fMRI) and includes healthy participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, but criteria met sufficiently to include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study of theory-of-mind/mental-state reasoning during social vs non-social tasks, directly addressing social processing. Abstract describes task-based fMRI and reports typical neural correlates; no indication of patient groups or that it’s a review. Appears to involve healthy adult participants, meeting inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review.

The study reports resting-state cerebellar connectivity in adults with autism spectrum disorder and analyses of structural differences; it does not describe an fMRI social-related task. It also focuses on an ASD population with no clear task-based healthy adult group reported. Thus it fails the inclusion criterion of task-based social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with an observe/imitate emotional face task in healthy adult participants; assesses social cognitive processes (emotion recognition, social inference). Meets meta-analysis objective of social processing in healthy adults and no exclusion criteria evident.

The article is a narrative review of aIPS function across studies, not an original fMRI experiment. It is a review/meta-analytic type paper (reviews human and monkey experiments) and does not report primary fMRI data of healthy adults performing social tasks; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Study focuses on structural MRI subtyping in individuals with autism spectrum disorder and includes resting-state fMRI analyses; it does not report task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults (ages 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study examining functional connectivity during anger/reactive aggression using script-driven tasks; unclear whether healthy adult controls are included and whether task qualifies as social processing. Insufficient detail in abstract—include for full-text review.

Sample comprises adolescents (developmental sample), not healthy adults in the 17–65 range, and reported neural measures index risk processing and cognitive control rather than social-related task activation; does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating impression updating (perception/understanding of others), clearly a social-related task and empirical fMRI work (not a review). Abstract does not report participant health status or ages, so insufficient information to confirm healthy adults 17–65. Include for full-text review to verify sample eligibility.

The study reports an fMRI experiment probing social cognition (predicting others' behavior, theory-of-mind vs deontic inference) in 18 participants (healthy adults implied). It is primary research (not a review) and involves a social-related task during functional MRI, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 14 healthy adult participants (within 17–65) performing a social-related task (observing others' pupil dynamics); directly investigates neural processing of social signals and is not a review.

Event-related fMRI study of emotion-word processing (social/affective language), includes a typically-developing control group (healthy participants). The task probes social-related processing (understanding/expressing emotions). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

Study used fMRI during a self-face recognition task (Perception and Understanding of Self), a social-related process, in human participants and is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract indicates healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used to measure neural responses to observed actions (mirror system) in participants; this addresses social cognitive processing (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults and the paper is empirical, not a review.

Abstract references neural correlates of social interaction but does not specify use of functional MRI or provide participant health/age details. Information is insufficient to confirm fMRI and healthy adult sample, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a social interactive task (virtual handshake; acceptance vs rejection) and includes a healthy control group (n=16). Participants are adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

The abstract states this is a review of model-based approaches (a review article), not a primary fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not present original fMRI data in healthy adults.

Participants are autistic adolescents and typically developing adolescents/children; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. The review requires at least one healthy adult group; thus it does not meet inclusion criteria based on population.

fMRI study of pain empathy involving perspective-taking (social processing). Includes a healthy control group (21 adults) alongside patients, meeting the requirement for healthy participants aged within 17–65. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study with 44 healthy adult participants performing explicit social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) on vocal stimuli. This involves functional MRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of face processing/social-emotional perception (Thatcher illusion) with explicit social-attention manipulation. Includes a matched neurotypical control group of 20 young adults (healthy, within 17–65). Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural responses to direct vs. averted gaze (social cognition/theory-of-mind). Includes a matched healthy control group of adults and uses an in-scanner social task. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

The study investigates reward-circuitry responses to monetary and autism-relevant object images (trains, electronics), not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception of others). Although it includes a healthy control group, the task does not assess social cognition, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 93 healthy adult males performing the Taylor aggression paradigm (social provocation) probing social-emotional processing and decision-making. Meets inclusion: social-related task during fMRI and healthy adult sample (likely ages 17–65). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information.

Functional MRI study of social processing (empathy/sympathy). Sample age 7–40 includes adults within the 17–65 range and participants appear to be healthy; not a review or meta-analysis. Include for full-text to confirm adult subgroup details and health status.

Study used fMRI during a social cognition/intentional causality (Theory of Mind) task. The abstract reports group differences involving participants with ASD, implying a healthy control group was included. No exclusion criteria (review/meta-analysis) apply. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and other details.

Resting-state fMRI in sedated young children (mean age 4.98) with ASD and matched controls. Not a task-based social-processing fMRI study, and participants are children, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore does not meet population or task criteria.

The abstract describes a multi-method review/synthesis (including Neurosynth meta-analytic analyses, lesion work, TMS, MVPA) rather than reporting an original fMRI study of participants performing a social task. It is therefore a review/meta-analysis and meets the exclusion criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social attribution/mentalizing with healthy control group and BPD patients. Task probes perception/understanding of others; healthy adults are included and it is an original study (not a review). Information in abstract is sufficient to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining social communication (prosodic intent) in human participants. Abstract implies healthy participants but does not state ages or health status explicitly. Include for full-text review to confirm participant health and age (17–65) and other eligibility details.

Abstract reports an original fMRI study using a passive viewing task of disgusted faces to examine racial prejudice — a social perception/understanding of others task. It describes neural responses in healthy participants (no indication of patient groups) and is not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion for fMRI social-processing in adults; include for full-text review.

Study used fMRI during a validated social exclusion task (Cyberball), addressing social processing. It includes a healthy control group of adults alongside clinical groups, and is an original research article (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy subjects performing a familiarity judgment of personally familiar vs famous/unfamiliar faces—task probes social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Abstract lacks participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

fMRI study using social-emotional tasks (gender identification of angry and happy faces) addressing perception/understanding of others; reports healthy adult sample (N=30). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study using a social attribution task (inferring causes of others’ emotional behaviors) and includes a healthy control group (n=16). This fits the review’s social processing constructs and the requirement for ≥1 healthy adult group. Not a review/meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study examining neural processing of race and socioeconomic status—social perception of others—using 61 healthy adult (white male) participants. It directly studies social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a social task (recognition of own child’s facial emotions — perception/understanding of others/attachment). Includes a healthy adult group (mothers without current mental disorders). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Sample comprises 13-year-old adolescents (mean age ~13), which falls outside the review’s required healthy adult age range (17–65). Although it used fMRI during a social exclusion task, the participant age criterion is not met.

Whole-brain fMRI study on integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions, addressing social perception/understanding of others. Abstract lacks explicit participant health status and ages; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (healthy adults 17–65).

fMRI study with healthy adult (male) fans performing an emotional memory retrieval task tied to fan identity/affiliation and social perspective; investigates social-cognition-related processes using functional MRI. Not a review and meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI studies where participants (healthy American and Korean adults) completed persuasion tasks engaging social-cognitive/mentalizing processes (perception/understanding of others). Methods are empirical fMRI (not a review). Age ranges not specified in abstract, but participants are described as adult samples; include for full-text to confirm exact ages.

fMRI study measuring brain activity while participants viewed emotional faces (social-related task: perception of others). Includes a healthy control group alongside Huntington’s gene carriers. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating animacy perception/mentalizing—social cognitive processes—using animated figures and neural responses. Meets review objective of social-related fMRI in adults. Abstract does not specify participant demographics/age range, so include for full-text to confirm at least one healthy adult group (17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social processing (self/other understanding in romantic relationships) with 42 healthy adult participants; task addresses perception/understanding of self and others and affiliation/attachment constructs. Not a review or meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports functional neuroimaging of two groups of (presumably healthy) football supporters while they watched match videos, probing group bias and social-cognitive processing (interpretation/evaluation of others). This is a social-related fMRI task in human adults and is not a review. Age range not explicitly given, so small uncertainty, but inclusion criteria are otherwise met.

The fMRI task probes anticipation of pain/fear while viewing physical exercise videos, not a social-related task (affiliation, communication, or understanding others). Although authors note activation in regions linked to social cognition, the paradigm does not assess social processing. Healthy controls included, but study does not meet the social-processing objective.

This study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although it includes healthy adult cohorts and discusses social-processing regions, it does not involve participants completing a social-related task as required by the inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study investigating explicit social reward (agreement with music experts) that includes 17 matched stimulant‑naive healthy controls. Task assesses social processing and meets inclusion criteria.
This study is itself a quantitative meta-analysis of fMRI studies (systematic review/meta-analysis), and the exclusion criteria specify meta-analyses/systematic reviews should be excluded.

This is a resting-state fMRI study with no task-based social-related processing. Although healthy controls are included, the review requires fMRI during a social-related task; therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no task manipulation) to predict gender. The review requires task-based functional MRI during social-related processing in healthy adults. Although participants are healthy, there is no social task or measurement of social processing reported in the abstract, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study with 27 healthy adult participants (age within 17–65), testing social interaction/intention understanding (mentalizing and action understanding). Not a review/meta-analysis; directly assesses social-related processing using fMRI, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports a functional neural (fMRI) study in healthy adult participants using a socio-affective video task involving witnessing others’ distress—this targets social processing (compassion/affiliation). It measured neural activations during a social-related task and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports altered brain activation during action imitation and observation (mirror neuron system) in schizophrenia, implying brain imaging during social-related tasks. Although it does not explicitly state fMRI or mention healthy control subjects, the study likely includes controls and neuroimaging; insufficient details for exclusion—include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and presence of healthy adults.

Abstract reports fMRI during a social cognition task (imagining personally familiar others), matching ‘perception and understanding of others’. It is an empirical fMRI study (not a review). The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; therefore include for full-text review to confirm at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65.

Three fMRI experiments examine neural responses to dynamic vs static facial expressions—social perception/communication relevant to review objective. Study reports original data (not a review) and likely involves healthy adult participants; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in Williams syndrome patients and controls rather than a functional MRI scan during a social-related task. It does not meet the requirement of task-based social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract addresses theory-of-mind and neural networks in CHR youth but does not specify whether an fMRI was used or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Not a review. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

The fMRI task was the Embedded Figures Task, a visual/perceptual task rather than a social-related task. Although authors report correlations with social impairment and face-processing regions, the task itself does not probe social processing constructs required by the review. At least one healthy control group is present, but the primary inclusion criterion (social-related task) is not met.
Resting-state fMRI in adolescents (no task-based social processing) — does not involve a social-related task in healthy adults aged 17-65, so fails inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring neural responses to affective facial expressions (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Includes an independent replication sample of healthy adults (n=85). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of empathizing (social processing) with a typically developing control group present. Abstract reports controls aged 12–31, so it is unclear whether the healthy group meets the review’s 17–65 age requirement; insufficient information to determine inclusion solely from abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and extract relevant data.

Abstract discusses neural mechanisms of information sharing (social-related processing) but does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or specify participant age/health. Insufficient information to confirm fMRI in healthy adults from abstract alone—include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study of an interactive face-to-face joint attention task (social processing) with at least two healthy adult neurotypical groups (n=14 and n=22) of likely ages 17–65. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

The fMRI tasks (saccadic and pursuit eye movements) probe sensorimotor control, not social-related processing. Although a healthy control group was included, the study does not address social constructs required by the review.

Study used resting-state fMRI (dynamic functional network connectivity) rather than an fMRI task involving social-related processing. Although it includes healthy controls, it does not report a social task, so it does not meet the review’s task-based social processing inclusion criterion.

Abstract lacks necessary methodological details: it does not state whether an fMRI was used during a social-related task or report participant ages. Title implies neuroimaging and unaffected siblings (likely healthy adults), but this is insufficient to confirm inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to determine if fMRI social task and 17–65 healthy group are present.

fMRI study using an incidental social task (viewing emotional faces during gender discrimination) assessing responses in social-processing regions (amygdala, sgACC). Involves healthy adult genotype groups; meets inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study involving healthy adult participants (sighted and congenitally blind) performing/observing actions; investigates mirror system and perception/understanding of others (social cognition). Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task during fMRI). Not a review.

fMRI was used while healthy male and female participants made social decisions (free vs. controlled by another person). The study examines social cognition and neural mechanisms underpinning control aversion in healthy adults and is not a review—fits inclusion criteria.

Study involves fMRI in young children with autism (clinical sample) and reports treatment prediction; no evidence of a healthy adult (age 17–65) control group. Population does not meet inclusion criterion of healthy adults, so exclude.

Event-related fMRI study with 51 healthy adult participants performing an emotional sentence classification task (affective speech comprehension) probing theory-of-mind and social cognition networks. This directly addresses social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports two fMRI experiments probing perception of social actions (person presence, orientation, action directedness), which fits 'Perception and Understanding of Others' and the review objective. The abstract does not state participant health/ages; likely healthy adults but not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation (social task involving a psychotherapist) in adult participants; examines attachment and social cognition/DMN. No indication of clinical-only sample. Meets social-related constructs and inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study of emotion attribution/self-other processing (empathy), addressing perception/understanding of self and others. Reports neural activations in healthy adult subjects during social-related tasks. Meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

fMRI study explicitly investigates social-related processing (anticipatory interpersonal touch; animate vs inanimate targets). No indication it is a review/meta-analysis or that participants are nonhealthy. Abstract does not specify participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Abstract reports an imaging study investigating brain activation during emotion processing (a social-related task) in unaffected siblings of schizophrenia patients, who are healthy participants. It meets the fMRI + social processing criteria and is not a review; include for full-text review.

Primary fMRI study (N=23 mothers) examining neural responses to own/standard infant videos—addresses affiliation/attachment social processing. Participants are healthy adult mothers (within typical adult age range). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets task and population inclusion criteria.
The paper is itself a systematic review and meta-analyses of fMRI studies (as indicated by the title and abstract). The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses.
This is a brief review of neuroimaging findings in autism (a review article), not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. Excluded per criteria: systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Study used fMRI while healthy adult participants viewed and learned faces, addressing perception and recognition of others (a social-related process). Participants are healthy humans; task involves social stimuli (faces). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsfMRI) rather than a task-based functional MRI during a social-related task. The review requires fMRI while participants perform social processing tasks; resting-state connectivity does not meet this inclusion criterion. Although healthy adult controls are included and the topic is social cognition, no task-based social fMRI is reported in the abstract.

This study used EEG (ERPs and time-frequency analyses), not functional MRI. Inclusion requires a functional MRI scan during a social-related task; modality mismatch excludes the study despite healthy adult participants and relevant social/gossip task.

fMRI study where participants performed a risky-choice task influenced by expert advice (a social influence paradigm). Reports neural activity in social-cognition regions (TPJ, vmPFC). Includes healthy adult group (18+). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.
Animal study using mouse rs-fcMRI; no human participants and no task-based social processing. Does not meet inclusion criteria of human fMRI during social-related task in healthy adults.

fMRI study using theory-of-mind tasks (emotions, beliefs, pain) in 46 volunteers—addresses social processing in humans. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages not stated, 'volunteers' implies healthy adult participants; insufficient detail for age exclusion, so include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an imaging study (NeuroImage) using an interactive virtual-reality task probing joint attention — a social cognitive process — and identifies neural correlates of initiating/responding to joint attention. It appears to involve healthy adult participants and meets the review objective. Abstract lacks explicit ages but provides sufficient evidence of fMRI in a social task; include for full-text review to confirm sample details.

fMRI study using functional neuroimaging in human listeners to discriminate auditory emotions (social communication/perception of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and directly examines social-related processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Four fMRI experiments (n=98) examined social processing (closeness/similarity) during judgments about self, friends, and unknown others. Participants are healthy adults; task is social-related (affiliation/attachment, perception of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The study investigates birdsong and references fMRI data in songbirds (non-human). It does not involve functional MRI in human participants performing social-related tasks, so it fails the human fMRI inclusion criterion.

Task: multiround trust game during fMRI, which is a social-related task (perception/interaction). Includes a healthy comparison group of women. Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.
The study used transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) rather than functional MRI; it does not report fMRI scanning during a social task, so it does not meet the fMRI inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports neural activation in response to romantic (affiliation/attachment) and sexual stimuli in monogamous and non-monogamous adult men (n=10 per group), indicating a functional neuroimaging task probing social/affiliation processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (e.g., review/meta-analysis) are met; study aligns with review objective.

fMRI study examining neural responses to facial emotions related to attachment/affiliation in a sample of 51 healthy adults (adult age range). Task involves social-emotional face processing; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports neuroimaging of trustworthiness appraisal (social-related task) comparing BPD to controls, indicating at least one healthy control group and social cognitive processing; meets inclusion for fMRI social task and healthy adults. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social-related processing (direct and reflected self- and other-evaluations). Includes a healthy young adult group (ages 22–31), which meets the 17–65 criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI (BOLD) study in healthy participants performing a task involving subjective evaluation of emotional conflicts with clear social-cognitive components (STS, IPL implicated). Abstract lacks participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age criteria and detailed methods.

fMRI study in healthy subjects examining self vs other recognition (perception/understanding of self and others), which fits the social-related constructs. Abstract reports original fMRI data in healthy adults; not a review. Age range not specified but 'healthy subjects' suggests inclusion—full text can confirm ages.

The article is explicitly a review summarizing ERP and fMRI findings rather than a primary fMRI study. It is therefore a systematic/narrative review and does not report original fMRI data from healthy adults completing social tasks, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Abstract does not specify use of functional MRI or that participants (healthy adults) completed a social-related fMRI task. Title implies brain/hormone study but insufficient detail to confirm eligibility. Include for full-text review to determine whether fMRI social processing in healthy adults was performed.

fMRI study in 21 healthy men undergoing a social-evaluation task (negative social feedback), addressing social cognition/perception constructs. Involves healthy adult participants and uses task-based fMRI. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social attention (eye-gaze) in typically developing adults; task involves perception of others’ gaze (social processing). Includes healthy adult participants (typical adults). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining emotion recognition from dynamic avatars—clearly a social-perception task (perception/understanding of others). Subjects underwent fMRI; likely healthy adult participants though ages not specified. Abstract provides enough to include for full-text review to confirm participant age/health.

fMRI was used and the task involved a social interaction and manipulation of self-perspective (out-of-body vs in-body), which maps onto ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ and social processing. Participants appear to be healthy adults, and this is an original fMRI study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text extraction.

This study used positron emission tomography (PET), not functional MRI. The meta-analysis specifically targets fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults, so the imaging modality does not meet inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social processing; although it examines peer influences behaviorally, no social task fMRI is reported in the abstract.

Original fMRI study using a social-rejection (Cyberball) task, addressing social processing. Sample includes an adult group (16 adult female participants) alongside adolescents, implying healthy adults within the 17–65 range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore meets inclusion criteria.

Study uses neuroimaging of emotional face processing (social perception of others), which fits the social-related fMRI task criterion. The abstract implies neural imaging but does not state participant health status or ages. Because participant characteristics are unclear, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility. Not a review/meta-analysis.
Participants are children in middle childhood (ages 8–12); does not meet inclusion age criterion of healthy adults aged 17–65.

Study participants are adolescents (title states adolescents with autism and their siblings); does not meet inclusion criterion of healthy adults aged 17–65. Although task and fMRI are relevant, age group excludes study.

Study reports an fMRI facial emotion processing task (social-related processing) and includes a healthy control group (27 participants). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria for full-text data extraction.

Randomized, double-blind fMRI study during an interactive social task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) assessing neural and behavioral responses to intranasal oxytocin and vasopressin in healthy adult males and females. Meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; not a review.

fMRI study investigating cross-modal recognition of others (face/voice), addressing social perception of others. Uses functional MRI during a social-recognition task. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health, but sufficient evidence of social-related fMRI task—include for full-text screening to confirm participant details.

fMRI study during an imaginary sentence completion task involving contemplation of mothers/fathers (social/attachment processing). Includes a healthy control group (15 volunteers, adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI was used with a social manipulation (standardized critical remarks) to probe processing of criticism, a social-evaluative task relevant to perception/understanding of others. The study used healthy adult participants. Abstract lacks explicit age range and task details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This article is a meta-analysis (systematic review of 21 studies), which matches an explicit exclusion criterion. Additionally, the abstract focuses on schizophrenia patients and does not report inclusion of a healthy adult group. Therefore it should be excluded.

This article is a systematic review and meta-analysis of imaging studies rather than an original fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults; per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews/meta-analyses are excluded.

The study examines cognitive regulation of emotional responses to positive/negative pictures, not social-related processing (no affiliation, communication, or self/other perception tasks described). Although it uses fMRI in healthy adults, the abstract does not report a social task or social stimuli, so it does not meet the review objective.

This record is a review and meta-analysis (systematic review) rather than an original fMRI study; exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' applies. Abstract does not report a primary fMRI study with healthy participants.

fMRI study of implicit facial emotion processing (fear vs neutral), which is social-related (Perception/Understanding of Others). Includes a healthy control group of adults (24 controls, age range likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining social communication processing (friend vs computer) during task; involves healthy participants and social-related constructs (social communication/mentalizing). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a functional MRI scan during a social-related task. Although it includes healthy controls, it does not assess task-based social processing in adults, so it does not meet the review's primary inclusion criterion.

Event-related fMRI in healthy nulliparous adult women responding to infant cries/faces—social-affiliation and perception of others constructs. Meets inclusion (social-related fMRI, healthy adult group). No exclusion criteria met. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.

The study uses resting-state fMRI and task-related coactivation-based parcellation; the abstract does not report participants performing a social-related task during fMRI. Although social cognition is mentioned in functional characterization, there is no evidence of task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis, but does not meet the inclusion requirement of a social task fMRI.

This paper is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies (activation likelihood estimation), meeting the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses'. Additionally, it focuses on psychopathy rather than reporting original fMRI data in healthy adults performing social tasks.

Study used magnetoencephalography (MEG), not functional MRI; the review requires fMRI studies. Although it investigates social cognition (theory of mind) in healthy adults, the imaging modality does not meet inclusion criteria.

Task-state fMRI examining self-referential processing (a social-related construct) and includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not report control participants' ages (likely older), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social cognition) using belief-processing tasks; addresses social-related processing in likely healthy adult participants. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Abstract is insufficient to determine eligibility: it does not state whether an fMRI social-related task was used (may be resting-state connectivity) nor whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Study focuses on ASD and ADHD co-occurrence. Include for full-text review to confirm task-based fMRI and presence of healthy participants.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing) and focused on individuals with autism; no evidence of a healthy adult task-based group. Does not meet inclusion criterion of task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of supraliminal fearful face processing (social/emotional perception) in adults; includes a healthy control group matched on age (healthy participants aged as adults), meeting the requirement for at least one healthy adult group. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study using event-related paradigm of gesture planning/execution (social communication/social action), includes a healthy adult control group (matched; likely ages 17–65), and is not a review. Abstract clearly describes social-related processing and healthy participants, meeting inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI study examining self-referential processing and perspective taking (social cognition constructs: perception/understanding of self and others). Appears to test participants (likely healthy adults) and is not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification.

Abstract does not report task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. Study uses resting-state connectivity, structural covariance, and meta-analytic connectivity modeling to characterize the left anterior insula, not an in-scanner social task.

The abstract reports fMRI connectivity in an ASD clinical sample and does not describe a social-related task or inclusion of a healthy adult task group. It likely uses resting-state or task-free connectivity and focuses on clinical severity, so it does not meet the review’s requirement for fMRI during social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of self- and other-referential perspective-taking (social processing) with 24 typically developed adult controls (healthy adults) and ASD group. Task and population meet inclusion criteria; not a review.

Abstract reports an fMRI hyperscanning study of joint attention, a social-related task (social interaction). Participant health/age not specified in abstract; insufficient to confirm healthy adult sample. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

Original fMRI study of cognitive empathy (social processing) with healthy control group participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages aren’t stated in the abstract, controls are reported and task is social-related, so it meets inclusion; include for full-text review.

Abstract examines self-referential processing (a social-related construct) and reports neural activation; however the abstract does not clearly state use of fMRI nor presence of healthy control group. Insufficient information to rule out inclusion — include for full-text review.

Abstract addresses perception of emotional faces (a social-related task linked to amygdala) but does not explicitly state use of functional MRI or presence of a healthy control group. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to determine fMRI methods and whether healthy adults (17–65) were studied.

fMRI experiment probing emotion recognition and gaze integration (social cognition/mentalizing). Includes a healthy younger participant group aged 17–27 (within 17–65 inclusion range). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI and behavioral measures of social cognition (emotion/sarcasm recognition), not a task-based fMRI scan during social-related processing. Although healthy controls were included, the key inclusion requirement—functional MRI while completing a social-related task—is not met.

Study examines children and adolescents with autism and integrates functional/structural connectivity; does not report fMRI in healthy adult participants (age 17–65). Therefore does not meet the requirement of including healthy adults.

Abstract reports correlational analysis relating SRS-A scores to functional connectivity (cingulo-insular/pregenual ACC) in neurotypical adults, with no indication of an fMRI social task. Likely resting-state connectivity rather than task-based social processing; thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI during a social-related task.

fMRI study of fearful face-processing (social-related task: perception/understanding of others). Includes a matched healthy adult control group alongside Asperger/HFA group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports oxytocin effects on processing of socially relevant cues in the human ventral tegmental area, which fits the social-related processing domain. However the abstract does not specify use of functional MRI or participant age/health details. Because key methodological/participant information is missing, include for full-text review to determine whether it used fMRI and healthy adult participants.

Abstract investigates neural correlates of facial emotion processing (social processing) in individuals at risk for psychosis; likely an fMRI study of face perception. The abstract does not explicitly state imaging modality or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Due to insufficient information in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm fMRI use and presence of a healthy adult group.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task). The review requires fMRI during a social-related task; although healthy control groups are included, no task-based social processing was performed, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI in adolescent patients and controls (not an active social-related task) and participants are adolescents (early-onset schizophrenia), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet task-based social processing or healthy adult population criteria.

Study used fMRI during a facial emotion perception task (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others) and includes a healthy control group of adults without MDD. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults based on the abstract.

Study sample comprises pediatric/adolescent participants with social anxiety (not adults); abstract does not indicate a healthy adult (age 17–65) group. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion age/sample criteria for the review.

Abstract reports oxytocin effects on neural activity (anterior insula) related to approach behavior to positive social stimuli, implying neuroimaging during a social task in humans. However the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI methods or participant health/ages. Include for full-text review to confirm fMRI task and healthy adult sample.

fMRI study with healthy adult bilinguals using fingerspelling (sign language), which may fall under 'Social Communication'. Abstract centers on phonological memory rather than explicit social processing; information is insufficient to rule out relevance. Include for full-text review to confirm whether task meets social-related constructs.

Abstract reports fMRI of a non-clinical (healthy) cohort performing the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, a social (Theory of Mind) task, meeting the review objective. Age range of healthy participants is not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study used resting-state fMRI (no task) and multimodal imaging to predict cognitive/symptom scores. Although it predicts a social cognition score, there was no functional MRI during a social-related task, so it does not meet the requirement for task-based social processing.

This study examines resting-state and diffusion imaging correlates of visuospatial working memory in adolescents with ASD and typically developing adolescents. It does not involve task-based fMRI of social-related processing, and participants are adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the review’s population or task criteria.

Resting-state fMRI study (no social task) in adolescents with ASD; does not include a task-based social processing paradigm or a healthy adult (17–65) group required by the review objective. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI studies comparing neural responses to person-related (famous people) and social abstract words versus other categories, indicating social-related processing tasks. Study uses human participants (implied healthy adults) and is an original fMRI study, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Study uses an fMRI precision visuomotor (sensorimotor) task in individuals with ASD, not a social-processing task, and participants are clinical (ASD) rather than healthy adults. Does not meet review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study used functional MRI during a theory-of-mind task (social cognition: Perception and Understanding of Others) in 109 healthy adult volunteers, directly matching the review objective and inclusion criteria. It is an original fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Original research using fMRI to study perspective selection (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample.

Abstract investigates fMRI connectivity related to emotional processing in Huntington’s disease but does not state whether task-based social-related fMRI was used or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Emotional processing may fall under social cognition, but details are insufficient—include for full-text review to confirm.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a functional MRI scan during a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing; although participants are healthy adults, no social task was administered, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports BOLD measures of the face-processing network in healthy adults but does not specify that fMRI was acquired during a social-related task; insufficient information to confirm task-based social processing. Include for full-text review to determine task vs resting-state and eligibility.

fMRI study investigating processing of communicative (social) gestures and mentalizing/mirror systems during observation and imitation—fits ‘social communication’ and fMRI modality. Involves 20 participants (presumably healthy adults). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Resting-state fMRI in children/adolescents (8–15) with ASD and controls; no task-based social processing paradigm; sample not healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet the review’s requirement for task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social processing (encoding with social faces) includes a typically developing healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages (described as “boys”), so inclusion criterion of adult participants (17–65) cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to verify ages and eligibility.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) and examines youth with autism rather than healthy adults aged 17–65; therefore does not meet the review’s task-based social processing and population criteria.

This article is a review summarizing and critically evaluating brain-imaging studies (not an original fMRI study). It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses. The abstract also does not report fMRI social-processing tasks in healthy adults.

The abstract investigates social-emotional action control relevant to social processing, but does not specify use of functional MRI or confirm sample are healthy adults (17–65). Insufficient information on imaging modality and participant details; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract does not specify whether an fMRI social-task was used or whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. Topic concerns social interactive processing and likely involves fMRI, but information is insufficient to confirm eligibility. Include for full-text review to determine task details and presence of healthy controls.

Study used fMRI during a social-cognition task (modified Sally-Anne) assessing inference of others' social emotions; includes a matched healthy control group (17 typically developing males). Abstract does not specify participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm they meet 17–65 age criterion.

Study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm and focuses on ASD; does not report task-based social-related fMRI in healthy adults as required by inclusion criteria.
